Simple Linear Regression

Introduction

We often think that there exists an inherent relationship between variables.

We will be concerned with building statistical models which describe the dependence of variable of interest (called the response, outcome, dependent variable, ...) on a colleciton of other related variables (called predictors, regressors, covariates, ...)

The model

This course studies the relationship between the mean/average response and the predictor in a linear framework, e.g,

E(y∣x)=β0+β1xE(y |x) = \beta_0 +\beta_1x E(y∣x)=β0​+β1​x

where β0\beta_0β0​ is the intercept and β1\beta_1β1​ is the slope.

More qualtitatively, we can attribute this as:

Response = Noise + Signal\text{Response = Noise + Signal} Response = Noise + Signal

The signal is the variation in response explained in terms of predictors, and a small number of unknown parameters (the systematic part of themodel).

The noise is residual variation unexplained in the systematic part of the model (this part may also describe some unknown parameters.)

Almost no systems that we encounter in the real world can be explained by two variables - thus we always expect some noise.

Consider fitting the regression line to all the points. In this case, we assume no noise; but this is overfitting the model.

Consider fitting the regression line as a flat horizontol line of Yˉ\bar{Y}Yˉ. This is underfitting, as we have not tried to predict yyy with our predictor.

The simple linear regression model is built of the premise of distance from the regression line. In particular, the y value in an (x, y) point pair and it's vertical distance from the line is how we find the regression line.

Consider the list of vectors (x0, y0), (x1, y1), ... which represents our observed sample. Also consider some regression line:

β0+β1x\beta_0 + \beta_1x β0​+β1​x

Then, our epsilons, are calculated by:

ϵi=∣yi−(β0+β1xi)∣\epsilon_i = |y_i - (\beta_0 + \beta_1x_i)| ϵi​=∣yi​−(β0​+β1​xi​)∣

ϵi\epsilon_iϵi​ is considered our random error. Thus, an observed value of yyy is given by:

y=β0+β1x+ϵy = \beta_0 + \beta_1 x + \epsilon y=β0​+β1​x+ϵ

We assume the following:

  • E(ϵi)=0E(\epsilon_i) = 0E(ϵi​)=0
  • Var(ϵi)=σ2\text{Var}(\epsilon_i) = \sigma^2Var(ϵi​)=σ2

Least squares estimation

Choose the least squares estimators b0b_0b0​ and b1b_1b1​ to minimise the goodness of fit criterion

S(β0,β1)=∑i=1n(yi−E(yi))2=∑i=1n(yi−β0−β1xi)2S(\beta_0, \beta_1) = \sum_{i=1}^n (y_i - E(y_i))^2 = \sum_{i=1}^n (y_i - \beta_0 - \beta_1x_i)^2 S(β0​,β1​)=i=1∑n​(yi​−E(yi​))2=i=1∑n​(yi​−β0​−β1​xi​)2

The sum of squares notation is given by:

Given the vector of responses y=(y1,...,yn)y = (y_1, ..., y_n)y=(y1​,...,yn​) and predictors x=(x1,...,xn)x = (x_1, ..., x_n)x=(x1​,...,xn​) , we write:

Syy=∑i=1n(yi−yˉ)2S_{yy} = \sum_{i=1}^n (y_i - \bar{y})^2 Syy​=i=1∑n​(yi​−yˉ​)2

Sxx=∑i=1n(xi−xˉ)2S_{xx} = \sum_{i=1}^n (x_i - \bar{x})^2 Sxx​=i=1∑n​(xi​−xˉ)2

Sxy=∑i=1n(xi−xˉ)(yi−yˉ)S_{xy} = \sum_{i=1}^n (x_i - \bar{x})(y_i - \bar{y}) Sxy​=i=1∑n​(xi​−xˉ)(yi​−yˉ​)

Therefore, our values of b0b_0b0​ and b1b_1b1​ are given by:

  • b0=yˉ−b1xˉb_0 = \bar{y} - b_1\bar{x}b0​=yˉ​−b1​xˉ
  • b1=SxySxxb_1 = \frac{S_{xy}}{S_{xx}}b1​=Sxx​Sxy​​

Let us prove this to ourselves for more clarity. First, declare:

S(β0,β1)=∑i=1n(yi−β0−β1xi)2S(\beta_0, \beta_1) = \sum_{i=1}^n (y_i - \beta_0 - \beta_1x_i)^2 S(β0​,β1​)=i=1∑n​(yi​−β0​−β1​xi​)2

We must find the partial derivatives for β0\beta_0β0​ and β1\beta_1β1​.

∂β0=−∑i=1n2(yi−β0−β1xi)∂β1=−∑i=1n2xi(yi−β0−β1xi) \begin{align*} \partial_{\beta_0} &= - \sum_{i=1}^n2(y_i - \beta_0 - \beta_1x_i) \\ \partial_{\beta_1} &= - \sum_{i=1}^n2x_i(y_i - \beta_0 - \beta_1x_i) \end{align*}∂β0​​∂β1​​​=−i=1∑n​2(yi​−β0​−β1​xi​)=−i=1∑n​2xi​(yi​−β0​−β1​xi​)​

Letting the partial derivatives =0= 0=0, we find the normal equations:

∑i=1n2(yi−β0−β1xi)=0∑i=1n2xi(yi−β0−β1xi)=0 \begin{align*} \sum_{i=1}^n2(y_i - \beta_0 - \beta_1x_i) &= 0 \\ \sum_{i=1}^n2x_i(y_i - \beta_0 - \beta_1x_i) &= 0 \end{align*}i=1∑n​2(yi​−β0​−β1​xi​)i=1∑n​2xi​(yi​−β0​−β1​xi​)​=0=0​

Then, by resolving these summations, we get to the values of ebta listed above.

Some lemmas

For some estimators b0b_0b0​ and b1b_1b1​ of β0\beta_0β0​ and β1\beta_1β1​:

E(bi)=βiE(b_i) = \beta_i E(bi​)=βi​

The variance of b1b_1b1​ is given by

σ2Sxx\frac{\sigma^2}{S_{xx}} Sxx​σ2​

The variance of b0b_0b0​ is given by

σ2n+σ2xˉ2Sxx\frac{\sigma^2}{n} + \frac{\sigma^2\bar{x}^2}{S_{xx}} nσ2​+Sxx​σ2xˉ2​

The covariance of b1b_1b1​ and b0b_0b0​ is given by

−σ2xˉ2Sxx-\frac{\sigma^2\bar{x}^2}{S_{xx}} −Sxx​σ2xˉ2​

Linear regressions in R

The below example is for the market data example.

setwd("~/data") # or whatever the working dir of your data is.
market <- read.table("Market.txt", header=T)
plt(market$Market, market$Host_International)
beta <- lm(Host_International ~ market,data=market) # regress y ~ x, from a data variable market.
summary(beta) # gives a summary of the regression analysis
beta$residuals # gives us the residuals; the error for each observed value
coef(beta) # the coefficients
beta$coefficients # another way of seeing the coefficients

Estimation of the error variance

  • Since ϵi=yi−b0−b1xi\epsilon_i = y_i - b_0 - b_1x_iϵi​=yi​−b0​−b1​xi​ and the variance of epsilon is σ2\sigma^2σ2, a natural estimator is:

σ^2=1n∑i=1n(yi−b0−b1xi)2\hat{\sigma}^2 = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n(y_i - b_0 - b_1x_i)^2 σ^2=n1​i=1∑n​(yi​−b0​−b1​xi​)2

  • However, this estimator is biased.
  • We can modify the estimator to:

    1n−2∑i=1n(yi−b0−b1xi)2\frac{1}{n-2}\sum_{i=1}^n(y_i - b_0 - b_1x_i)^2 n−21​i=1∑n​(yi​−b0​−b1​xi​)2

  • By losing two degrees of freedom, we make the estimator unbiased.

MLE of Linear Regression Parameters

First, assume that ϵi∼N(0,σ2)\epsilon_i \sim N(0, \sigma^2)ϵi​∼N(0,σ2). By the linear regression model, this means that yi∼N(β0+β1xi,σ2)y_i \sim N(\beta_0 + \beta_1x_i, \sigma^2)yi​∼N(β0​+β1​xi​,σ2).

Thus, we can find the density function of yiy_iyi​ by:

fY(yi)=12πσ2e−12σ2(yi−β0−β1xi2)f_Y(y_i)= \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma^2}}e^{-\frac{1}{2\sigma^2}(y_i-\beta_0 - \beta_1x_i^2)} fY​(yi​)=2πσ2​1​e−2σ21​(yi​−β0​−β1​xi2​)

Therefore, our likelihood function becomes:

L(β0,β1,σ2;y)=∏i=1n...L(\beta_0, \beta_1, \sigma^2; y) = \prod_{i=1}^n ... L(β0​,β1​,σ2;y)=i=1∏n​...

L=exp⁡(−12σ2S(β0,β1))(12πσ2)nL = \exp\left( -\frac{1}{2\sigma^2}S(\beta_0, \beta_1)\right)\left( \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma^2}}\right)^n L=exp(−2σ21​S(β0​,β1​))(2πσ2​1​)n

By applying the log likelihood, and then finding for the maximum value of the first derivative, we arrive at:

∑i=1n(yi−β0−β1xi)2\sum_{i=1}^n(y_i - \beta_0 - \beta_1x_i)^2 i=1∑n​(yi​−β0​−β1​xi​)2

otherwise, the same estimator as we were given earlier. Thus, this estimator is the MLE of yiy_iyi​.

You can use the same log function as found above and then derive partially with respects to σ2\sigma^2σ2, and then find the value that maximises σ^2\hat{\sigma}^2σ^2.

Summary of notations

The response is denoted by yiy_iyi​ and the model assumption tells us that:

yi=β0+β1xi+ϵiy_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1x_i + \epsilon_i yi​=β0​+β1​xi​+ϵi​

The mean response E(yi)E(y_i)E(yi​) is given by

E(yi)=β0+β1xiE(y_i) = \beta_0 + \beta_1x_i E(yi​)=β0​+β1​xi​

The fitted values of the response are given by yi^\hat{y_i}yi​^​ for i=1,...,ni=1,..., ni=1,...,n

yi^=b0+b1xi\hat{y_i}=b_0 + b_1x_i yi​^​=b0​+b1​xi​

The residuals of the fitted model are given by ei,i=1,...,ne_i, i=1,..., nei​,i=1,...,n

ei=yi−yi^e_i = y_i - \hat{y_i} ei​=yi​−yi​^​

The Fundamental Identity

SStotal=SSreg+SSresSS_\text{total} = SS_\text{reg} + SS_\text{res} SStotal​=SSreg​+SSres​

or, in plain terms:

total sum of squares=regression sum of squares+residual sum of squares\text{total sum of squares} = \text{regression sum of squares} + \text{residual sum of squares} total sum of squares=regression sum of squares+residual sum of squares

where subbing in the identities we get

∑(yi−yˉ)2=∑(yi^−yˉ)2+∑(yi−y^)2\sum (y_i - \bar{y})^2 = \sum (\hat{y_i} - \bar{y})^2 + \sum(y_i - \hat{y})^2 ∑(yi​−yˉ​)2=∑(yi​^​−yˉ​)2+∑(yi​−y^​)2

Proof

∑(yi−yˉ)2=∑(yi−yi^+yi−yˉ)=∑(yi−yi^)2+∑(yi^−yˉ)2+2∑(yi−yi^)(yi^−yˉ)\begin{align*} \sum(y_i -\bar{y})^2 &= \sum (y_i - \hat{y_i} + y_i - \bar{y}) \\ &= \sum(y_i-\hat{y_i})^2 + \sum (\hat{y_i} - \bar{y})^2 + 2\sum (y_i-\hat{y_i})(\hat{y_i} -\bar{y}) \end{align*} ∑(yi​−yˉ​)2​=∑(yi​−yi​^​+yi​−yˉ​)=∑(yi​−yi​^​)2+∑(yi​^​−yˉ​)2+2∑(yi​−yi​^​)(yi​^​−yˉ​)​

So we must prove that the last element is 0. Since

∑(yi−yi^)=∑(yi−b0−b1xi)=0\sum (y_i - \hat{y_i}) = \sum (y_i - b_0 - b_1x_i) = 0 ∑(yi​−yi​^​)=∑(yi​−b0​−b1​xi​)=0

and by a similar argument, the LHS multiple of the term is also zero; thus, proving our identity.

Coefficient of Determination

One way to assess the goodness of fit of a model is by looking at the coefficient of determination R2R^2R2 given by:

R2=SSregSStotalR^2 = \frac{SS_{reg}}{SS_{total}} R2=SStotal​SSreg​​

We want R2R^2R2 to be close to 1 to have a good goodness of fit. It essentially finds how much our regression explains the variance of the total variance.

Thus, the higher the R2R^2R2 value, the less noise (given by our residuals) we have.

An example using R

setwd("~/data")
market <- read.table("Abalone.txt", header=T)
model <- lm(Host_International ~ market,data=market)
summary(model)$r.squared # This will contain the R-squared value.

Analysis of residuals and error terms

We have previously talked about residuals, the difference between the observed value and then model value

ei=yi−y^ie_i = y_i - \hat{y}_i ei​=yi​−y^​i​

plot(predict(model), model$residuals)

plot(model) # This takes you through 6 plots for residuals analysis.
We want the red line (which considers the plot of the residuals) to be as close to as zero as possible.

The second plot is a QQ plot of the residuals - we want the residuals to be distributed normally, as we assume that the error term is normally distributed.

Things to look out for

  • Shape in the residual vs fitted: If there is any shape in the residuals vs fitted graph, then there is some signal that you have not accounted for in your model yet.
  • Cone shape: If there is a cone shape or a tapering shape in your residuals vs fitted graph - the assumption that the variance in your error term is constant throughout your model is not correct.
  • Violation of normality: If there is a large violation of normality (on the QQ plot analysis); then our linear model assumptions are again violated.

Revision of distributions derived from normal

Chi-squared distribution

The chi-squared distribution with nnn-degrees of freedom, denoted by χn2\chi_n^2χn2​, is defined as the sum of squares of nnn independent standard normal random variables Z1,...,ZnZ_1, ..., Z_nZ1​,...,Zn​

∑i=1nZi2∼χn2\sum_{i=1}^n Z_i^2 \sim \chi_n^2 i=1∑n​Zi2​∼χn2​

  • Suppose Z∼N(0,1)Z \sim N(0, 1)Z∼N(0,1) then Z2∼χ12Z^2 \sim \chi_1^2Z2∼χ12​
  • Suppose X∼χn2X \sim \chi_n^2X∼χn2​ and Y∼χm2Y \sim \chi_m^2Y∼χm2​ and X and Y are independent, then

X+Y∼χn+m2X + Y \sim \chi_{n+m}^2 X+Y∼χn+m2​

  • If X∼χn2X \sim \chi_n^2X∼χn2​ then E(X)=nE(X) = nE(X)=n and Var(X)=2n\text{Var}(X) = 2nVar(X)=2n.

t-distribution

The t-distribution with nnn degrees of freedom, denoted by tnt_ntn​ is defined as the ratio of two independent random variables

T=ZX/nT = \frac{Z}{\sqrt{X/n}} T=X/n​Z​

or

Xˉ−μS/n∼tn−1\frac{\bar{X} -\mu}{S/\sqrt{n}} \sim t_{n-1} S/n​Xˉ−μ​∼tn−1​

but we must consider the degrees of freedom removed (consider that in the linear regression model, there are two degrees of freedom used.)

where Z∼N(0,1)Z \sim N(0, 1)Z∼N(0,1) and X∼χn2X \sim \chi_n^2X∼χn2​ is independent of ZZZ.

Write T∼tnT \sim t_nT∼tn​, we say TTT has ttt distribution with n degrees of freedom.

F-distribution

The Fisher's F-distribution with m and n degrees of freedom, denoted by Fm,nF_{m, n}Fm,n​ is defined as a ratio of two independent chi-squared random variables, each divided by its degrees of freedom

F=X1/mX2/nF = \frac{X_1/m}{X_2/n} F=X2​/nX1​/m​

where X1∼χm2X_1\sim\chi_m^2X1​∼χm2​, X2∼χn2X_2 \sim \chi_n^2X2​∼χn2​ and X1andX2X_1 and X_2X1​andX2​ are independent.

Distribution theory of estimators the betas and variance

In the simple linear regression model

yi=β0+β1xi+ϵiy_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1x_i + \epsilon_i yi​=β0​+β1​xi​+ϵi​

under the assumption that the errors ϵi,i=1,...,n\epsilon_i, i=1, ..., nϵi​,i=1,...,n are independent and normally distributed, ei∼N(0,σ2)e_i \sim N(0, \sigma^2)ei​∼N(0,σ2), the least square estimators b0b_0b0​ and b1b_1b1​ are normally distributed, σ^2\hat{\sigma}^2σ^2 is independent of b0b_0b0​ and b1b_1b1​ and

b0∼N(β0,σ2(1n+xˉ2Sxx))b1∼N(β1,σ2Sxx)(n−2)σ^2σ2∼χn−22\begin{align*} b_0 &\sim N(\beta_0, \sigma^2\left( \frac{1}{n} + \frac{\bar{x}^2}{Sxx}\right)) \\ b_1 &\sim N(\beta_1, \frac{\sigma^2}{S_xx}) \\ \frac{(n-2)\hat{\sigma}^2}{\sigma^2} &\sim\chi_{n-2}^2 \end{align*} b0​b1​σ2(n−2)σ^2​​∼N(β0​,σ2(n1​+Sxxxˉ2​))∼N(β1​,Sx​xσ2​)∼χn−22​​

Some lemmas

Considering the above properties:

b0−β0σ^(1n+xˉ2Sxx)∼tn−2\frac{b_0 - \beta_0}{\hat{\sigma}\sqrt{\left(\frac{1}{n} + \frac{\bar{x}^2}{S_{xx}} \right)}} \sim t_{n-2} σ^(n1​+Sxx​xˉ2​)​b0​−β0​​∼tn−2​

b1−β1σ^Sxx∼tn−2\frac{b_1 - \beta_1}{\frac{\hat{\sigma}}{\sqrt{S_{xx}}}} \sim t_{n-2} Sxx​​σ^​b1​−β1​​∼tn−2​

Thus, inference on β0\beta_0β0​ and β1\beta_1β1​ can be done by:

(b1−tα,n−2σ^Sxx,b1+tα/2;n−2σSxx)\left( b_1 - t_{\alpha,n-2} \frac{\hat{\sigma}}{\sqrt{S_{xx}}} , b_1 + t_{\alpha/2;n-2}\frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{S_{xx}}}\right) (b1​−tα,n−2​Sxx​​σ^​,b1​+tα/2;n−2​Sxx​​σ​)

Hypothesis testing for the betas

Use the results for the distributions of b0,b1b_0, b_1b0​,b1​ and σ^2\hat{\sigma}^2σ^2 to test hypotheses about β0\beta_0β0​ and β1\beta_1β1​.

To test the hypothesis

H0:βj=βH_0 : \beta_j = \beta H0​:βj​=β

versus the alternative

H1:βj≠βH_1 : \beta_j \neq \beta H1​:βj​=β

(j = 0, 1) we use the test statistic

T=bj−βse^(bj)T = \frac{b_j - \beta}{\hat{\text{se}}(b_j)} T=se^(bj​)bj​−β​

which has a tn−2t_{n-2}tn−2​ distribution under H0H_0H0​.

Importantly, to test for a linear relationship between xxx and yyy, we want to test:

H0:β1=0H_0 : \beta_1 = 0 H0​:β1​=0

H1:β1≠0H_1 : \beta_1 \neq 0 H1​:β1​=0

The output of the lm() function in R gives you the test statistic and p-value for this test.

Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) table

Another way to test the hypotheses:

H0:β1=0H_0 : \beta_1 = 0 H0​:β1​=0

H1:β1≠0H_1 : \beta_1 \neq 0 H1​:β1​=0

is with an F-test. When we test the hypothesis with an F-test, we are asking ourselves:

Is the predictor in the linear regression model at all useful for explaining variation in the response?

In the simple linear regression model, the F-test gives us the same values as the t-test, but this is not necessarily true for general linear models. Recall that:

T=b1σ^/Sxx∼tn−2T = \frac{b_1}{\hat{\sigma}/\sqrt{S_xx}}\sim t_{n-2} T=σ^/Sx​x​b1​​∼tn−2​

squaring TTT, we get an FFF statistic:

T2=F=b12Sxxσ^2∼F1,n−2T^2 = F = \frac{b_1^2 S_xx}{\hat{\sigma}^2} \sim F_{1, n-2} T2=F=σ^2b12​Sx​x​∼F1,n−2​

In a simple linear regression model, SSreg=b12SxxSS_{reg} = b_1^2S_xxSSreg​=b12​Sx​x, and σ^2=SSres/(n−2)\hat{\sigma}^2 = SS_{res}/(n-2)σ^2=SSres​/(n−2). So we now have an FFF test statistic and its distribution under H0:β1=0H_0 : \beta_1 = 0H0​:β1​=0 give by:

F=SSregSSres/(n−2)=MSregMSres∼F1,n−2F = \frac{SS_{reg}}{SS_{res}/(n-2)} = \frac{MS_{reg}}{MS_{res}} \sim F_{1, n-2} F=SSres​/(n−2)SSreg​​=MSres​MSreg​​∼F1,n−2​

where MSMSMS is the mean sum of squared, the sum of squares divided by the numbers of degrees of freedom.

It can be seen that the FFF statistic is a ratio of the regression and residual sums of squares. If the variation explained by the model is much larger than the residual variation, then FFF will have ea largue value, and we will reject the null hypothesis that the predictors are not useful in predicting the response.

To find the ppp-value with the FFF statistic, we find:

P(F>Fα,1,n−2)P(F > F_{\alpha, 1, n-2}) P(F>Fα,1,n−2​)

The analysis of variance (ANOVA) table below shows the decomposition of total variation into SSregSS_{reg}SSreg​ and SSresSS_{res}SSres​ and the computation of the FFF statistic. ![[anova.png]]

Making a new prediction

Under our linear regression model, a new response y0=y(x0)y_0 = y(x_0)y0​=y(x0​) when the predictor is x0x_0x0​ can be expressed as:

y(x0)=β0+β1x0+ϵ0y(x_0) = \beta_0 + \beta_1x_0 + \epsilon_0 y(x0​)=β0​+β1​x0​+ϵ0​

The true mean response at a value x0x_0x0​ is (which is the value from the model):

E(y(x0))=β0+β1x0E(y(x_0)) = \beta_0 + \beta_1x_0 E(y(x0​))=β0​+β1​x0​

We can predict the mean response at a value x0x_0x0​ by:

y^(x0)=b0+b1x0\hat{y}(x_0) = b_0 + b_1x_0 y^​(x0​)=b0​+b1​x0​

and from this, our aim is to find a confidence interval for E(y(x0))=β0+β1x0E(y(x_0)) = \beta_0 + \beta_1x_0E(y(x0​))=β0​+β1​x0​ as well as a prediction interval for y0y_0y0​.

Finding the components

The expectation of y^\hat{y}y^​ is:

E(y^(x0))=E(b0+b1x0)=β0+β1x0\begin{align*} E(\hat{y}(x_0)) &= E(b_0 + b_1x_0) \\ &= \beta_0 + \beta_1x_0 \end{align*} E(y^​(x0​))​=E(b0​+b1​x0​)=β0​+β1​x0​​

The variance of y^\hat{y}y^​ is:

Var(y^(x0))=Var(b0+b1x0)=Var(b0)+x02Var(b1)+2x0Cov(b1,b0)=σ2n+σ2xˉ2Sxx+x02σ2Sxx−2x0σ2xˉSxx=σ2(1n+(x0−xˉ2)Sxx) \begin{align*} \text{Var}(\hat{y}(x_0)) &= \text{Var}(b_0 + b_1x_0) \\ &= \text{Var}(b_0) + x_0^2\text{Var}(b_1) + 2x_0\text{Cov}(b_1, b_0) \\ &= \frac{\sigma^2}{n} + \frac{\sigma^2\bar{x}^2}{S_xx} + x_0^2\frac{\sigma^2}{S_{xx}} - 2x_0\frac{\sigma^2\bar{x}}{S_{xx}} \\ &= \sigma^2\left(\frac{1}{n} + \frac{(x_0 - \bar{x}^2)}{S_{xx}} \right) \end{align*} Var(y^​(x0​))​=Var(b0​+b1​x0​)=Var(b0​)+x02​Var(b1​)+2x0​Cov(b1​,b0​)=nσ2​+Sx​xσ2xˉ2​+x02​Sxx​σ2​−2x0​Sxx​σ2xˉ​=σ2(n1​+Sxx​(x0​−xˉ2)​)​

Confidence interval for a new prediction

Therefore:

y^(x0)∼N(β0+β1x0,σ2(1n+(x0−xˉ2)Sxx))\hat{y}(x_0) \sim N\left(\beta_0 + \beta_1x_0, \sigma^2\left(\frac{1}{n} + \frac{(x_0 - \bar{x}^2)}{S_{xx}} \right)\right) y^​(x0​)∼N(β0​+β1​x0​,σ2(n1​+Sxx​(x0​−xˉ2)​))

Thereby:

y^(x0)−β0−β1x0σ^1n+(x0−xˉ)2Sxx∼tn−2\frac{\hat{y}(x_0) - \beta_0 - \beta_1x_0}{\hat{\sigma}\sqrt{\frac{1}{n} + \frac{(x_0-\bar{x})^2}{S_{xx}}}} \sim t_{n-2} σ^n1​+Sxx​(x0​−xˉ)2​​y^​(x0​)−β0​−β1​x0​​∼tn−2​

and thus, creating a confidence interval is fairly straight forward from here.

Simultaneous estimation of the betas

There arises an issue with the simultaneous estimation of β0 \beta_0β0​ and β1\beta_1β1​.

Suppose we have separate 95% confidence intervals constructed for β0\beta_0β0​ and β1\beta_1β1​. This implies that in 5% of the samples, calculated confidence intervals may not cover the true slope and another, possibly 5% may not cover the true intercept. In fact, as much as 10% of the samples could be incorrect for either or both parameters!

Bonferroni inequality

Consider the simultaneous estimation of β0\beta_0β0​ and β1\beta_1β1​. Suppose we set that:

A0={β0∉CI0,α}A_0 = \{ \beta_0 \notin CI_{0, \alpha} \} A0​={β0​∈/CI0,α​}

A1={β1∉CI1,α}A_1 = \{ \beta_1 \notin CI_{1, \alpha} \} A1​={β1​∈/CI1,α​}

where CIi,αCI_{i, \alpha}CIi,α​ is a 100(1−α)%100(1 - \alpha)\%100(1−α)% confidence interval for Bi,i=0,1B_i, i=0, 1Bi​,i=0,1. This implies that:

  • P(β0∈CI0,α)=1−αP(\beta_0 \in CI_{0, \alpha}) = 1-\alphaP(β0​∈CI0,α​)=1−α
  • P(β1∈CI1,α)=1−αP(\beta_1 \in CI_{1, \alpha}) = 1-\alphaP(β1​∈CI1,α​)=1−α
  • P(β0∈CI0,α∩β1∈CI1,α)=P(A0c∩A1C)P(\beta_0 \in CI_{0, \alpha} \cap \beta_1 \in CI_{1, \alpha}) = P(A_0^c \cap A_1^C)P(β0​∈CI0,α​∩β1​∈CI1,α​)=P(A0c​∩A1C​)

The Bonferroni inequality is defined by:

P(A0c∩A1c)≥1−2αP(A_0^c \cap A_1^c) \ge 1 - 2\alpha P(A0c​∩A1c​)≥1−2α

Bonferroni adjustment

  • In general, suppose we have parameters θ0,...,θk\theta_0, ..., \theta_kθ0​,...,θk​. It can be shown that if we construct pointwise 100(1−α/k)%100(1-\alpha/k)\%100(1−α/k)% confidence intervals for all the parameters, then the joint coverage of these estimators has a CI of 100(1−α)%100(1-\alpha)\%100(1−α)%
  • Thus, the correction for our confidence interval is to divide our desired significane level α\alphaα by the number of parameters kkk.
  • The Bonferroni adjustment is conservative.

General Linear Model

Previously we considered having one predictor - however, in real experiments, there may be multiple parameters. The general linear model allows for multiple predictors.

Given nnn responses y1,...,yny_1, ..., y_ny1​,...,yn​ and the values of kkk predictor variables, we have:

yi=β0+β1xi1+β2xi2+...+βkxik+ϵiy_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1x_{i1} + \beta_2x_{i2} + ... + \beta_kx_{ik} + \epsilon_i yi​=β0​+β1​xi1​+β2​xi2​+...+βk​xik​+ϵi​

where β0,...,βk\beta_0, ..., \beta_kβ0​,...,βk​ are unknown parameters and ϵi\epsilon_iϵi​ is a collection of independent errors with zero mean and variance σ2\sigma^2σ2.

Matrix formulation of the GLM

Consider the above general linear model. We have some new notation:

y=(y1,...,yn)Txj=(x1j,...,xnj)Tβ=(β0,...,βk)Tϵ=(ϵ1,...,ϵn)T\begin{align*} y &= (y_1, ..., y_n)^T \\ x_j &= (x_{1j}, ..., x_{nj})^T \\ \beta &= (\beta_0, ..., \beta_k)^T \\ \epsilon &= (\epsilon_1, ..., \epsilon_n)^T \end{align*} yxj​βϵ​=(y1​,...,yn​)T=(x1j​,...,xnj​)T=(β0​,...,βk​)T=(ϵ1​,...,ϵn​)T​

such that these are all column vectors.

  • Let p=k+1p = k + 1p=k+1, such that ppp is the length of β\betaβ.
  • Write XXX for the n×pn \times pn×p matrix whose 1st column is a column of 1's and the (j + 1)th column is the vector xj=(x1j,...,xnj)T,j=1,...,kx_j = (x_{1j}, ..., x_{nj})^T, j=1, ..., kxj​=(x1j​,...,xnj​)T,j=1,...,k
  • In other words, the first column is 1's, and the rest of the column vectors are each of the predictors observations.

In matrix form, the general linear model is given by:

(y1...yn)=(1x11...x1k............1xn1...xnk)(β0...βk)+(ϵi...ϵn)\begin{pmatrix} y_1 \\ ... \\ y_n \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & x_{11} & ... & x_{1k} \\ ... & ... & ... & ... \\ 1 & x_{n1} & ... & x_{nk} \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} \beta_0 \\ ... \\ \beta_k \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} \epsilon_i \\ ... \\ \epsilon_n \end{pmatrix} ​y1​...yn​​​=​1...1​x11​...xn1​​.........​x1k​...xnk​​​​β0​...βk​​​+​ϵi​...ϵn​​​

or more simply:

y=Xβ+ϵy = X\beta + \epsilon y=Xβ+ϵ

Least squares estimation

A natural extension of the goodness of fit criterion considered for the simple linear regression model is to minimise the sum of squared deviations between responses yyy and their predictions (expected values) XβX\betaXβ given by:

S(β)=∑i=1n(yi−(Xβ))2=∑i=1n(yi−∑j=0kxijβj)2S(\beta)=\sum_{i=1}^n (y_i - (X\beta))^2 = \sum_{i=1}^n(y_i - \sum_{j=0}^k x_{ij}\beta_{j})^2 S(β)=i=1∑n​(yi​−(Xβ))2=i=1∑n​(yi​−j=0∑k​xij​βj​)2

S(β)=(y−Xβ)T(y−Xβ)S(\beta) = (y - X\beta)^T(y-X\beta) S(β)=(y−Xβ)T(y−Xβ)

The objective stays the same: we wish to minimise the sum of the squares, which will lead to our least squares estimation.

Matrix form resolution

Observe that:

(y−Xβ)T(y−Xβ)=yT(y−Xβ)−(Xβ)T(y−Xβ)=yTy−yTXβ−βTXTy+βTXTXβ=yTy−(XTy)Tβ−βTXTy+βTXTXβ\begin{align*} (y-X\beta)^T(y-X\beta) &= y^T(y-X\beta) - (X\beta)^T(y-X\beta) \\ &= y^Ty - y^TX\beta - \beta^TX^Ty + \beta^TX^TX\beta \\ &= y^Ty - (X^Ty)^T\beta - \beta^TX^Ty + \beta^TX^TX\beta \end{align*} (y−Xβ)T(y−Xβ)​=yT(y−Xβ)−(Xβ)T(y−Xβ)=yTy−yTXβ−βTXTy+βTXTXβ=yTy−(XTy)Tβ−βTXTy+βTXTXβ​

however we know that βTXTy\beta^TX^TyβTXTy is a scalar. We know that the transpose of a scalar is itself, thus:

βT(XTy)=(XTy)Tβ\beta^T(X^Ty) = (X^Ty)^T\beta βT(XTy)=(XTy)Tβ

Therefore, the least squares criterion becomes:

(y−Xβ)T(y−Xβ)=yTy−2(Xty)Tβ+βTXTXβ(y-X\beta)^T(y-X\beta) = y^Ty - 2(X^ty)^T\beta + \beta^TX^TX\beta (y−Xβ)T(y−Xβ)=yTy−2(Xty)Tβ+βTXTXβ

An important identity is: XTXX^TXXTX, which we denote XTX=AX^TX = AXTX=A.

Vector function differentiation

For a real valued vector function fff, which maps a ppp-dimensional vector of real numbers x=(x1,...,xp)Tx = (x_1, ..., x_p)^Tx=(x1​,...,xp​)T to a real number f(x)f(x)f(x), we define the derivative of fff with respect to xxx as the vector:

∂f(x)∂x=(∂f(x)∂x1,...,∂f(x)∂xp)T\frac{\partial f(x)}{\partial x} = \left( \frac{\partial f(x)}{\partial x_1}, ..., \frac{\partial f(x)}{\partial x_p}\right)^T ∂x∂f(x)​=(∂x1​∂f(x)​,...,∂xp​∂f(x)​)T

Vector differentiation essentially works in some given vector space

Deriving beta using the least squares criterion

∂∂β(y−Xβ)T(y−Xβ)=∂∂β(yTy−2(XTy)Tβ+βTXTXβ)=−2XTy+(XTX+(XTX)T)β=−2XTy+2XTXβ\begin{align*} \frac{\partial}{\partial\beta}(y-X\beta)^T(y-X\beta) &= \frac{\partial}{\partial\beta}(y^Ty - 2(X^Ty)^T\beta + \beta^TX^TX\beta) \\ &= -2X^Ty + (X^TX + (X^TX)^T)\beta \\ &= -2X^Ty + 2X^TX\beta \end{align*} ∂β∂​(y−Xβ)T(y−Xβ)​=∂β∂​(yTy−2(XTy)Tβ+βTXTXβ)=−2XTy+(XTX+(XTX)T)β=−2XTy+2XTXβ​

Therefore the least squares estimator bbb of β\betaβ satisfies:

−2XTy+2XTXb=0-2X^Ty + 2X^TXb = 0 −2XTy+2XTXb=0

Which we have the normal equations:

(XTX)b=XTy(X^TX)b = X^Ty (XTX)b=XTy

If the model is full rank, then (XTX)(X^TX)(XTX) is invertible and the normal equations have a unique solution given by:

b=(XTX)−1(XTy)b = (X^TX)^{-1}(X^Ty) b=(XTX)−1(XTy)

Reminders from linear algebra

Vectors v1,...,,vpv_1, ...,,v_pv1​,...,,vp​ are said to be linearly dependent if there are some constants a1,...,apa_1, ..., a_pa1​,...,ap​ not all zero such that:

a1v1+...+apvp=0a_1v_1 + ... + a_pv_p = 0 a1​v1​+...+ap​vp​=0

The rank of a metrix is the maximal number of linearly independent columns; or all the leading rows in a matrix after row reduction.

Full rank model

A full rank model is a model which has nnn rows and ppp columns; and then has a rank of ppp. This means that all of the regressors are linearly indepdendent, and define their own signal.

Random vectors

We consider a random vector, which is a column vector of:

(Y1Y2...Yn) \begin{pmatrix} Y_1 \\ Y_2 \\ ... \\ Y_n \end{pmatrix}​Y1​Y2​...Yn​​​

The elements of which are jointly distributed random variables YiY_iYi​ with:

E(Yi)=μiE(Y_i) = \mu_i E(Yi​)=μi​

for i=1,2,...,ni = 1, 2, ..., ni=1,2,...,n and

Cov(yi,yj)=σi,jCov(y_i, y_j) = \sigma_{i, j} Cov(yi​,yj​)=σi,j​

for i,j=1,2,...,ni, j = 1, 2, ..., ni,j=1,2,...,n

Mean vector

The mean vector, is then defined by:

E(Y)=μ=(μ1,...,μn)TE(Y) = \mu = (\mu_1, ..., \mu_n)^T E(Y)=μ=(μ1​,...,μn​)T

Some results are:

  • If aaa is a k x 1 vector of constants, then E(a)=aE(a) = aE(a)=a
  • If aaa is a k x 1 vector of constants and YYY is an n x 1 random vector with E(Y)=μE(Y) = \muE(Y)=μ, then E(aTY)=aTμE(a^TY) = a^T\muE(aTY)=aTμ
  • If AAA is a p x n matrix of constants and YYY is a random vector with E(Y)=μE(Y) = \muE(Y)=μ, then E(AY)=AμE(AY) = A\muE(AY)=Aμ.

Thus, E(y=Xβ+ϵ)=XβE(y = X\beta + \epsilon) = X\betaE(y=Xβ+ϵ)=Xβ.

Covariance matrix

The covariance matrix of YYY denoted by Var(Y)\text{Var}(Y)Var(Y) is defined to be a square n×nn\times nn×n matrix containing the covariance of YiY_iYi​ and YjY_jYj​ at the (i,j)(i, j)(i,j)-th cell.

It can be defined as the matrix, for some random vector YYY, as:

(Y−μ)(Y−μ)T(Y-\mu)(Y-\mu)^T (Y−μ)(Y−μ)T

such that the (i,j)(i, j)(i,j)-th entry is defined by: (Yi−μi)(Yj−μj)(Y_i - \mu_i)(Y_j - \mu_j)(Yi​−μi​)(Yj​−μj​).

Lemma: Let YYY be a n×1n \times 1n×1 random vector with Var(Y)=V\text{Var}(Y) = VVar(Y)=V.

  1. If aaa is a n×1n \times 1n×1 vector of real numbers, then

Var(aTY)=aTVa\text{Var}(a^TY) = a^TVa Var(aTY)=aTVa

  1. Let AAA be a p×np \times np×n matrix. If Z=AYZ = AYZ=AY, then:

Var(Z)=AVAT\text{Var}(Z) = AVA^T Var(Z)=AVAT

Mean vector and covariance matrix of b

We found earlier that in the full rank model, the least squares estimator is b=(XTX)−1XTyb = (X^TX)^{-1}X^Tyb=(XTX)−1XTy. bbb is unbiased, such that:

E(b)=β\mathbb{E}(b) = \beta E(b)=β

with covariance matrix

Var(b)=σ2(XTX)−1\text{Var}(b) = \sigma^2(X^TX)^{-1} Var(b)=σ2(XTX)−1

Proofs

E(b)=E((XTX)−1XTy)=(XTX)−1XTE(y)=(XTX)−1XTXβ=X−1X−TXTXβ=β\begin{align*} \mathbb{E}(b) &= \mathbb{E}((X^TX)^{-1}X^Ty) \\ &= (X^TX){-1}X^T\mathbb{E}(y) \\ &= (X^TX){-1}X^TX\beta \\ &= X^{-1}X^{-T}X^TX\beta \\ &= \beta \end{align*} E(b)​=E((XTX)−1XTy)=(XTX)−1XTE(y)=(XTX)−1XTXβ=X−1X−TXTXβ=β​

Using the fact that for a nonsingular matrix AAA, (AT)−1=(A−1)T(A^T)^{-1} = (A^{-1})^T(AT)−1=(A−1)T:

Var(b)=(XTX)−1XTVar(y)((XTX)−1XT)T=(XTX)−1XT(σ2I)((XTX)−1XT)T=σ2(XTX)−1XT(X−1X−TXT)T=σ2(XTX)−1XT(X−1)T=σ2(XTX)−1\begin{align*} \text{Var}(b) &= (X^TX)^{-1}X^T\text{Var}(y)((X^TX)^{-1}X^T)^T \\ &= (X^TX)^{-1}X^T (\sigma^2I)((X^TX)^{-1}X^T)^T \\ &= \sigma^2(X^TX)^{-1}X^T(X^{-1}X^{-T}X^T)^T \\ &= \sigma^2(X^TX)^{-1}X^T(X^{-1})^T \\ &= \sigma^2(X^TX)^{-1} \end{align*} Var(b)​=(XTX)−1XTVar(y)((XTX)−1XT)T=(XTX)−1XT(σ2I)((XTX)−1XT)T=σ2(XTX)−1XT(X−1X−TXT)T=σ2(XTX)−1XT(X−1)T=σ2(XTX)−1​

Gauss Markov Theorem

bbb is an example of a lienar estimator, which is an estimator of the form AyAyAy for some p×np\times np×n matrix A.

The Gauss-Markov Theorem states that if b∗b^{*}b∗ is any unbiased linear estimator of β\betaβ, and if bbb is the least squares estimator, then Var(bi)≤Var(bi∗),i=1,...,p\text{Var}(b_i) \le \text{Var}(b_i^{*}), i = 1, ..., pVar(bi​)≤Var(bi∗​),i=1,...,p.

We say that bbb is the best linear unbiased estimator (BLUE) of β\betaβ.

Proof. Let b∗b^{*}b∗ be an arbitrary linear unbiased estimator of β\betaβ. We can write this estimator in the form:

b∗=((XTX)−1XT+B)yb^{*} = ((X^TX)^{-1}X^T + B)y b∗=((XTX)−1XT+B)y

for some p×np \times np×n matrix BBB

The expectation of the estimator is given by:

E(b∗)=((XTX)−1XT+B)Xβ\mathbb{E}(b^{*}) = ((X^TX)^{-1}X^T + B)X\beta E(b∗)=((XTX)−1XT+B)Xβ

=β+BXβ= \beta + BX\beta =β+BXβ

Since we know that b∗b^{*}b∗ is unbiased, we know that BXβ=0BX\beta = 0BXβ=0. For this to hold for arbitrary β\betaβ, we must have BX=0BX = 0BX=0.

Now consider:

Var(b∗)=Var(((XTX)−1XT+B)y)=((XTX)−1XT+B)σ2I((XTX)−1XT+B)T=σ2((XTX)−1XT+B)(X(XTX)−1+BT)=σ2((XTX)−1XTX(XTX)−1+(XTX)−1XTBT+BX(XTX)−1+BBT)\begin{align*} \text{Var}(b^{*}) &= \text{Var}(((X^TX)^{-1}X^T+B)y) \\ &= ((X^TX)^{-1}X^T + B)\sigma^2I((X^TX)^{-1}X^T + B)^T \\ &= \sigma^2((X^TX)^{-1}X^T + B)(X(X^TX)^{-1} + B^T) \\ &= \sigma^2((X^TX)^{-1}X^TX(X^TX)^{-1} + (X^TX)^{-1}X^TB^T \\ &+ BX(X^TX)^{-1} + BB^T) \end{align*} Var(b∗)​=Var(((XTX)−1XT+B)y)=((XTX)−1XT+B)σ2I((XTX)−1XT+B)T=σ2((XTX)−1XT+B)(X(XTX)−1+BT)=σ2((XTX)−1XTX(XTX)−1+(XTX)−1XTBT+BX(XTX)−1+BBT)​

But we previously deduced that BX=0BX=0BX=0, and equally, that XTBT=0X^TB^T=0XTBT=0, hence:

Var(b∗)=σ2((XTX)−1+BBT)\text{Var}(b^{*}) =\sigma^2((X^TX)^{-1} + BB^T) Var(b∗)=σ2((XTX)−1+BBT)

Thus, the variance of b∗b^{*}b∗ is just the variance of bbb with an added positive element, as:

BBT=∑i=1nBij2BB^T = \sum_{i=1}^n B_{ij}^2 BBT=i=1∑n​Bij2​

Thereby, bbb is BLUE.

Maximum likelihood estimation of parameters

Assuming that ϵi∼N(0,σ2).\epsilon_i \sim N(0, \sigma^2).ϵi​∼N(0,σ2).

Beta

L(β,σ2;y)=∏i=1n12πσ2exp⁡(−12σ2(yi−(Xβ)i)2)=(2πσ2)−n/2exp⁡(−12σ2∑i=1(yi−(Xβ)i)2)=(2πσ2)−n/2exp⁡(−12(y−Xβ)T(y−Xβ))\begin{align*} L(\beta, \sigma^2; y) &= \prod_{i=1}^n \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma^2}} \exp\left( -\frac{1}{2\sigma^2}(y_i - (X\beta)_i)^2\right) \\ &= (2\pi \sigma^2)^{-n/2}\exp\left(-\frac{1}{2\sigma^2}\sum_{i=1}(y_i - (X\beta)_i)^2 \right) \\ &= (2\pi \sigma^2)^{-n/2}\exp\left(-\frac{1}{2}(y-X\beta)^T(y-X\beta)\right) \end{align*} L(β,σ2;y)​=i=1∏n​2πσ2​1​exp(−2σ21​(yi​−(Xβ)i​)2)=(2πσ2)−n/2exp(−2σ21​i=1∑​(yi​−(Xβ)i​)2)=(2πσ2)−n/2exp(−21​(y−Xβ)T(y−Xβ))​

where the log-likelihood becomes:

−n2log⁡(2π)−n2log⁡(σ2)−12σ2(y−Xβ)T(y−Xβ)-\frac{n}{2}\log(2\pi) - \frac{n}{2}\log(\sigma^2) - \frac{1}{2\sigma^2}(y-X\beta)^T(y-X\beta) −2n​log(2π)−2n​log(σ2)−2σ21​(y−Xβ)T(y−Xβ)

Thus, we arrive at the OLS (when derived w.r.t β\betaβ); meaning that the least square estimator bbb is also the MLE.

Variance

Differentiating the above log-likelihood function with respects to σ2\sigma^2σ2, we get:

∂σ2=−n2σ2+12σ4(y−Xβ)T(y−Xβ)\begin{align*} \partial_{\sigma^2} &= -\frac{n}{2\sigma^2} + \frac{1}{2\sigma^4}(y-X\beta)^T(y-X\beta) \\ \end{align*} ∂σ2​​=−2σ2n​+2σ41​(y−Xβ)T(y−Xβ)​

Solving for 000, we get:

n2σ~2=12σ~4(y−Xβ)T(y−Xβ)σ~2=1n(y−Xβ)T(y−Xβ)\begin{align*} \frac{n}{2\tilde{\sigma}^2} &= \frac{1}{2\tilde{\sigma}^4}(y-X\beta)^T(y-X\beta) \\ \tilde{\sigma}^2 &= \frac{1}{n}(y-X\beta)^T(y-X\beta) \end{align*} 2σ~2n​σ~2​=2σ~41​(y−Xβ)T(y−Xβ)=n1​(y−Xβ)T(y−Xβ)​

Traces

For a k×kk \times kk×k matrix XXX, the trace of XXX, written tr(X)\text{tr}(X)tr(X), is the sum of the diagonal elements of XXX:

tr(X)=∑i=1kXii\text{tr}(X) = \sum_{i=1}^kX_{ii} tr(X)=i=1∑k​Xii​

Let yyy be a k×1k \times 1k×1 random vector with E(y)=μ\mathbb{E}(y) = \muE(y)=μ and Var(y)=V\text{Var}(y) = VVar(y)=V. Let AAA be a k×kk \times kk×k matrix of real numbers. Then

E(yTAy)=tr(AV)+μTAμ\mathbb{E}(y^TAy) = \text{tr}(AV) + \mu^TA\mu E(yTAy)=tr(AV)+μTAμ

Unbiased estimator of variance

The unbiased estimator of σ2\sigma^2σ2 is given by:

σ^2=1n−p(y−Xb)T(y−Xb)\hat{\sigma}^2 = \frac{1}{n-p}(y-Xb)^T(y-Xb) σ^2=n−p1​(y−Xb)T(y−Xb)

where ppp is the total number of parameters in the model.

Inference in the general linear model

First let us define a multivariate normal distribution, which is required for us to make inferences on a multi-parameter model.

A random vector Y(n×1)Y (n \times 1)Y(n×1) is said to have a multivariate normal distribution with mean vector μ\muμ and covariance matrix Σ\SigmaΣ if it's density f(y;μ,Σ)f(y; \mu, \Sigma)f(y;μ,Σ) is given by:

f(y;μ,Σ)=1(2π)n/2∣Σ∣1/2exp⁡(−12(y−μ)TΣ−1(y−μ))f(y; \mu, \Sigma) = \frac{1}{(2\pi)^{n/2}|\Sigma|^{1/2}}\exp\left(-\frac{1}{2}(y - \mu)^T\Sigma^{-1}(y- \mu)\right) f(y;μ,Σ)=(2π)n/2∣Σ∣1/21​exp(−21​(y−μ)TΣ−1(y−μ))

where ∣Σ∣|\Sigma|∣Σ∣ denotes the determinant of Σ\SigmaΣ.

Comments:

  • Σ\SigmaΣ is invertible, symmetrical and positive definite.
  • Marginal distribution of each YiY_iYi​ is univariate normal, Yi∼N(μi,Σii)Y_i \sim N(\mu_i, \Sigma_ii)Yi​∼N(μi​,Σi​i).
  • The mean vector μ\muμ and covariance matrix Σ\SigmaΣ completely characterize a multivariate normal distribution.
  • The bivariate normal distribution corresponds to the case n=2n=2n=2.

Lemmas:

Let Y∼N(μ,Σ)Y \sim N(\mu, \Sigma)Y∼N(μ,Σ), where YYY is a n×1n \times 1n×1 multivaraite random normal vector.

Let AAA be a p×np \times np×n matrix. Then Z=AYZ= AYZ=AY is a multivariate random vector with mean AμA\muAμ and covariance matrix AΣATA\Sigma A^TAΣAT:

Z∼N(Aμ,AΣAT)Z \sim N(A\mu, A\Sigma A^T) Z∼N(Aμ,AΣAT)

Suppose that YYY is a n×1n \times 1n×1 multivariate normal random vector, Y∼N(μ,Σ)Y \sim N(\mu, \Sigma)Y∼N(μ,Σ), where, as usual, the covariance matrix Σ\SigmaΣ is non-singular and positive definite, and it's inverse is Σ−1\Sigma^{-1}Σ−1. Then the random variable (y−μ)TΣ−1(y−μ)(y - \mu)^T\Sigma^{-1}(y- \mu)(y−μ)TΣ−1(y−μ) (of quadratic form) has a χn2\chi_n^2χn2​ distribution.

Distribution of parameters

Distribution of b

In the full rank linear model, under the normality assumption ϵ∼N(0,σ2I)\epsilon \sim N(0, \sigma^2I)ϵ∼N(0,σ2I), the least squares estimator bbb of B\BetaB has a multivariate normal distribution with mean β\betaβ and covariance matrix σ2(XTX)−1\sigma^2(X^TX)^{-1}σ2(XTX)−1

b∼N(β,σ2(XTX)−1)b \sim N(\beta, \sigma^2(X^TX)^{-1}) b∼N(β,σ2(XTX)−1)

Distribution of sigma

σ^2\hat{\sigma}^2σ^2 is distributed by:

(n−p)σ^2σ2∼χn−p2\frac{(n-p)\hat{\sigma}^2}{\sigma^2} \sim \chi_{n-p}^2 σ2(n−p)σ^2​∼χn−p2​

and bbb and σ^2\hat{\sigma}^2σ^2 are independent.

Confidence interval for betas

Write cjj,j=0,...,kc_{jj}, j=0, ..., kcjj​,j=0,...,k for the diagonal elements of (XTX)−1(X^TX)^{-1}(XTX)−1. It follows from the previous theorem that:

bj−βjσcjj∼N(0,1)\frac{b_j - \beta_j}{\sigma\sqrt{c_{jj}}}\sim N(0, 1) σcjj​​bj​−βj​​∼N(0,1)

Dividing through with the distribution we found for σ^2\hat{\sigma}^2σ^2, we get:

(bj−βjσcjj)÷(n−p)σ^2σ2n−p∼tn−p\left( \frac{b_j - \beta_j}{\sigma\sqrt{c_{jj}}}\right) \div \sqrt{\frac{\frac{(n-p)\hat{\sigma}^2}{\sigma^2}}{n-p}} \sim t_{n-p} (σcjj​​bj​−βj​​)÷n−pσ2(n−p)σ^2​​​∼tn−p​

so

bj−βjσ^cjj∼tn−p\frac{b_j - \beta_j}{\hat{\sigma}\sqrt{c_{jj}}} \sim t_{n-p} σ^cjj​​bj​−βj​​∼tn−p​

Thereby, a 100(1−α)%100(1-\alpha)\%100(1−α)% confidence interval for βj\beta_jβj​ is given by

(bj−tα/2,n−pσ^cjj,bj+tα/2,n−pσ^cjj(b_j - t_{\alpha/2, n-p}\hat{\sigma}\sqrt{c_{jj}}, b_j + t_{\alpha/2, n-p}\hat{\sigma}\sqrt{c_{jj}} (bj​−tα/2,n−p​σ^cjj​​,bj​+tα/2,n−p​σ^cjj​​

Joint confidence region for the coefficients (confidence ellipse)

Previously we used Bonferroni adjustments to obtain a confidence region with a guaranteed coverage level by adjusting coverage of pointwise intervals.

In the general linear model, there is an alternative way of delivering confidence regions which have exact coverage (1−α)(1 - \alpha)(1−α) for the parameter vector β\betaβ.

It can be shown that:

(b−β)TXTX(b−β)σ2∼χp2\frac{(b - \beta)^T X^TX(b - \beta)}{\sigma^2} \sim \chi_p^2 σ2(b−β)TXTX(b−β)​∼χp2​

We can then show that the statistic:

(b−β)TXTX(b−β)pσ^2\frac{(b-\beta)^TX^TX(b-\beta)}{p\hat{\sigma}^2} pσ^2(b−β)TXTX(b−β)​

has an Fp,n−pF_{p, n-p}Fp,n−p​ distribution.

Therefore:

P[(b−β)TXTX(b−β)/(pσ^2)≤Fα;p,n−p]=1−αP\left[(b-\beta)^TX^TX(b-\beta)/(p\hat{\sigma}^2) \le F_{\alpha;p, n-p}\right] = 1-\alpha P[(b−β)TXTX(b−β)/(pσ^2)≤Fα;p,n−p​]=1−α

Hypothesis testing for betas

To test

H0:βj=γH_0 : \beta_j = \gamma H0​:βj​=γ

and

H1:βj≠γH_1 : \beta_j \neq \gamma H1​:βj​=γ

we use the test statistic:

T=bj−γσ^cjjT = \frac{b_j - \gamma}{\hat{\sigma}\sqrt{c_{jj}}} T=σ^cjj​​bj​−γ​

which has a tn−pt_{n-p}tn−p​ distribution under H0H_0H0​.

The rejection region then becomes:

T<−tα/2;n−p or T>tα/2;n−pT<-t_{\alpha/2;n-p} \text{ or } T > t_{\alpha/2;n-p} T<−tα/2;n−p​ or T>tα/2;n−p​

Confidence interval for the mean response and the prediction interval

Consider a set of new predictors x∗=(xi1,...,xik)Tx_{*} = (x_{i1}, ..., x_{ik})^Tx∗​=(xi1​,...,xik​)T.

A new response in the fitted model, y∗y_{*}y∗​ for which the values of the predictor variables are x∗1,...,x∗kx_{*1}, ..., x_{*k}x∗1​,...,x∗k​. Then:

y∗=x∗Tβ+ϵ∗y_* = x_*^T\beta + \epsilon_{*} y∗​=x∗T​β+ϵ∗​

Thus, the fitted value becomes:

y^(x∗)=x∗Tβ\hat{y}(x_{*}) = x_{*}^T\beta y^​(x∗​)=x∗T​β

We know from preivous results that bbb is a random normal vector, and x∗Tx_{*}^Tx∗T​ is a vector of real values; thus, y^(x∗)\hat{y}(x_*)y^​(x∗​). We can find it's distribution by finding the expected value and it's variance:

E(x∗Tβ)=x∗Tβ\mathbb{E}(x_{*}^T\beta) = x_{*}^T\beta E(x∗T​β)=x∗T​β

Var(x∗Tb)=x∗TVar(b)x∗=σ2x∗T(XTX)−1x∗\begin{align*} \text{Var}(x_{*}^Tb) &= x_{*}^T\text{Var}(b)x_{*} \\ &= \sigma^2x_{*}^T(X^TX)^{-1}x_{*} \end{align*} Var(x∗T​b)​=x∗T​Var(b)x∗​=σ2x∗T​(XTX)−1x∗​​

Therefore, x∗Tb∼N(x∗Tβ,σ2x∗T(XTX)−1x∗)x_{*}^Tb \sim N(x_{*}^T\beta, \sigma^2x_{*}^T(X^TX)^{-1}x_*)x∗T​b∼N(x∗T​β,σ2x∗T​(XTX)−1x∗​).

Thereby, normalising our distribution, we arrive to:

x∗Tb−x∗Tβσx∗T(XTX)−1x∗∼N(0,1)\frac{x_{*}^Tb - x_{*}^T\beta}{\sigma\sqrt{x_{*}^T(X^TX)^{-1}x_*}} \sim N(0,1) σx∗T​(XTX)−1x∗​​x∗T​b−x∗T​β​∼N(0,1)

and by the following derivation:

(n−p)σ^2σ2∼χn−p2x∗Tb−x∗Tβσx∗T(XTX)−1x∗÷(n−p)σ^2σ2n−p∼χn−p2x∗Tb−x∗Tβσ^x∗T(XTX)−1x∗∼χn−p2\begin{align*} \frac{(n-p)\hat{\sigma}^2}{\sigma^2} &\sim \chi_{n-p}^2 \\ \frac{x_{*}^Tb - x_{*}^T\beta}{\sigma\sqrt{x_{*}^T(X^TX)^{-1}x_*}} \div \sqrt{\frac{\frac{(n-p)\hat{\sigma}^2}{\sigma^2}}{n-p}} &\sim \chi_{n-p}^2 \\ \frac{x_{*}^Tb - x_{*}^T\beta}{\hat{\sigma}\sqrt{x_{*}^T(X^TX)^{-1}x_*}} &\sim \chi_{n-p}^2 \end{align*}σ2(n−p)σ^2​σx∗T​(XTX)−1x∗​​x∗T​b−x∗T​β​÷n−pσ2(n−p)σ^2​​​σ^x∗T​(XTX)−1x∗​​x∗T​b−x∗T​β​​∼χn−p2​∼χn−p2​∼χn−p2​​

Therefore the confidence interval for a fitted value y^(x∗)=x∗Tb\hat{y}(x_{*}) = x_{*}^Tby^​(x∗​)=x∗T​b is given by:

(x∗T±tα/2;n−pσ^x∗T(XTX)−1x∗)(x_{*}^T \pm t_{\alpha/2;n-p}\hat{\sigma}\sqrt{x_{*}^T(X^TX)^{-1}x_*}) (x∗T​±tα/2;n−p​σ^x∗T​(XTX)−1x∗​​)

Prediction interval

Similarly, the prediction interval or the error interval, given by:

y∗−y^∗=x∗Tβ+ϵ∗−x∗Tby_* - \hat{y}_* = x_{*}^T \beta + \epsilon_{*} - x_{*}^Tb y∗​−y^​∗​=x∗T​β+ϵ∗​−x∗T​b

The mean is clearly 000. To compute the variance:

Var(y∗−y^∗)=Var(ϵ∗)+Var(x∗Tb)=σ2+σ2x∗T(XTX)−1x∗=σ2(1+x∗T(XTX)−1x∗)\begin{align*} \text{Var}(y_* - \hat{y}_*) &= \text{Var}(\epsilon_*) + \text{Var}(x_{*}^Tb) \\ &= \sigma^2 + \sigma^2x_{*}^T(X^TX)^{-1}x_* \\ &= \sigma^2(1 + x_{*}^T(X^TX)^{-1}x_*) \end{align*} Var(y∗​−y^​∗​)​=Var(ϵ∗​)+Var(x∗T​b)=σ2+σ2x∗T​(XTX)−1x∗​=σ2(1+x∗T​(XTX)−1x∗​)​

Thereby, from a similar logic as above:

y∗−y^∗σ^1+x∗T(XTX)−1X∗∼tn−p\frac{y_* - \hat{y}_*}{\hat{\sigma}\sqrt{1 + x_{*}^T(X^TX)^{-1}X_*}} \sim t_{n-p} σ^1+x∗T​(XTX)−1X∗​​y∗​−y^​∗​​∼tn−p​

Adjusted R squared

The more factors we add, the more we risk overfitting. In fact, as we add more factors, our R2R^2R2 will continue to get better. For general linear models, we have the adjusted R2R^2R2, written Rˉ2\bar{R}^2Rˉ2.

Rˉ2\bar{R}^2Rˉ2 is given by scaling the residual and total sum of squares by the degrees of freedom they encounter:

Rˉ2=1−(n−1)SSres(n−p)SStotal=1−σ^(n−1)SStotal\bar{R}^2 = 1 - \frac{(n-1)SS_{res}}{(n-p)SS_{total}} = 1 - \frac{\hat{\sigma}(n-1)}{SS_{total}} Rˉ2=1−(n−p)SStotal​(n−1)SSres​​=1−SStotal​σ^(n−1)​

or in terms of R2R^2R2:

Rˉ2=1−n−1n−p(1−R2)\bar{R}^2 = 1 - \frac{n-1}{n-p}(1-R^2) Rˉ2=1−n−pn−1​(1−R2)

Sequential sum of squares

The anova table in R for general linear models has the sum of squares as a sequential sum of squares.

The sequential sum of squares is achieved by the following process:

  • For each variable, compared the fitted model with the current variable and all the variables that precede it, with the model with just the variables that precede it.
  • This means that for each variable, we are able to consider the effect that the current varaible had on the model's fit.

Consider a list of betas (β1,...,βk)(\beta_1, ..., \beta_k)(β1​,...,βk​). We partition β\betaβ into two groups, B=(β(0),β(1))B = (\beta^{(0)}, \beta^{(1)})B=(β(0),β(1)).

  • We write R(β(1)∣β(0))R(\beta^{(1)} | \beta^{(0)})R(β(1)∣β(0)) for the increase in SSregSS_{reg}SSreg​ when the predictors are corresponding to the parameters β(1)\beta^{(1)}β(1) compared to the model with just the β(0)\beta^{(0)}β(0) parameter.
  • Note that:

    R(β1,...,βk∣β0)=R(β1∣β0)+R(β2∣β0,β1)+...+R(βk∣β0,...,βk−1)R(\beta_1, ..., \beta_k|\beta_0) = R(\beta_1|\beta_0) + R(\beta_2|\beta_0, \beta_1) + ... + R(\beta_k|\beta_0, ..., \beta_{k-1}) R(β1​,...,βk​∣β0​)=R(β1​∣β0​)+R(β2​∣β0​,β1​)+...+R(βk​∣β0​,...,βk−1​)

Hypothesis testing in the GLM

  • Partial FFF-tests on a group of predictors compared with the model with all predictors let's us see how much the group of predictors composes the total variation
  • This is useful to see which groups of predictors are useful; which groups of predictors are useful together, etc.

In the general linear model, the FFF-test tests the null hypothesis:

H0:β1=...=βk=0H_0 : \beta_1 = ... = \beta_k = 0 H0​:β1​=...=βk​=0

versus

H1:Not all Bj=0,j=1,...,kH_1 : \text{Not all } B_j = 0, j = 1, ..., k H1​:Not all Bj​=0,j=1,...,k

The statistic is given by:

F=MSregMSres=SSreg/(p−1)SSres/(n−p)∼Fp−1,n−pF = \frac{MS_{reg}}{MS_{res}} = \frac{SS_{reg}/(p-1)}{SS_{res}/(n-p)} \sim F_{p-1,n-p} F=MSres​MSreg​​=SSres​/(n−p)SSreg​/(p−1)​∼Fp−1,n−p​

where the critical region is given by:

F≥Fα;p−1,n−pF \ge F_{\alpha;p-1, n-p} F≥Fα;p−1,n−p​

Testing model quality

Single model quality

By testing:

H0:β1=...=βk=0H_0: \beta_1 = ... = \beta_k =0 H0​:β1​=...=βk​=0

We consider if the model with just an intercept is better than the model with all the predictors. This is a good indicator of model quality.

Comparing models

We can compare a model of form:

yi=β0+β1xi1+...+βr−1xi(r−1)+ϵiy_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1x_{i1} + ... + \beta_{r-1}x_{i(r-1)} + \epsilon_i yi​=β0​+β1​xi1​+...+βr−1​xi(r−1)​+ϵi​

with a model:

yi=β0+β1xi1+...+βr−1xi(r−1)+βrxir+...+βkxik+ϵiy_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1x_{i1} + ... + \beta_{r-1}x_{i(r-1)} + \beta_{r}x_{ir} + ... + \beta_{k}x_{ik} + \epsilon_i yi​=β0​+β1​xi1​+...+βr−1​xi(r−1)​+βr​xir​+...+βk​xik​+ϵi​

we consider the null hypothesis:

H0:βr=βr+1=...=βk=0H_0: \beta_r = \beta_{r+1} = ... = \beta_{k} = 0 H0​:βr​=βr+1​=...=βk​=0

and

H1:not all betas are zeroH_1: \text{not all betas are zero} H1​:not all betas are zero

which considers if the extra predictors have significant predictive ability.

Sequential F-test

To describe a sequential FFF-test, consider the model

yi=β0+β1xi1+...+βj−1xi(j−1)+βjxij+ϵiy_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1x_{i1} + ... + \beta_{j-1}x_{i(j-1)} + \beta_jx_{ij} + \epsilon_i yi​=β0​+β1​xi1​+...+βj−1​xi(j−1)​+βj​xij​+ϵi​

where we test the hypothesis whether or not to include the jjj-th predictor in this model:

H0:βj=0 and H1:βj≠0H_0: \beta_j = 0 \text{ and } H_1 : \beta_j \ne 0 H0​:βj​=0 and H1​:βj​=0

We can then use the following test statistic and its null distribution:

F=R(βj∣β0,...,βj−1)MSres∼F1,n−(j+1)F = \frac{R(\beta_j | \beta_0, ..., \beta_{j-1})}{MS_{res}} \sim F_{1,n - (j+1 )} F=MSres​R(βj​∣β0​,...,βj−1​)​∼F1,n−(j+1)​

MSresMS_{res}MSres​ here refers to the residuals + the rest of the predictors that are not considered.

R-code

model1 <- lm(risk~Div+Ratio, data=risk)
model2 <- lm(risk~Div+Ratio+Size, data=risk)
anova(model1,model2)

Output:

Analysis of Variance Table

Response: INF
          Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value   Pr(>F)   
DEV        1 6222.7  6222.7 11.4884 0.003267 **
QUES       1 1122.5  1122.5  2.0724 0.167150   
LEGAL      1    0.3     0.3  0.0006 0.981197   
Residuals 18 9749.7   541.7

The Sum of Sq column gives the sequential sum of squares with the new predictor being compared with the predictors that are before it in the ANOVA table. For example, in the above lab question example; we get:

R(DEV∣B0)R(QUES∣DEV,B0)...R(\verb|DEV| | B_0) \\ R(\verb|QUES| | \verb|DEV|, B_0) \\ ... R(DEV∣B0​)R(QUES∣DEV,B0​)...

We generally want to keep the residuals (or any predictors we might want to discard) towards the end, because:

  1. The MSresMS_{res}MSres​ calculation becomes a lot easier.
  2. We can also check the sequential F-test that considers if it is additive to the model in any way.

Model Selection

We must manage a trade off between goodness of fit and complexity; or so called bias-variance tradeoff.

Model selection for prediction

We write M0M_0M0​ for the model:

yi=β0+ϵiy_i = \beta_0 + \epsilon_i yi​=β0​+ϵi​

in which the predictor xix_ixi​ is excluded, and write M1M_1M1​ for the full model:

yi=β0+β1xi+ϵiy_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1x_i + \epsilon_i yi​=β0​+β1​xi​+ϵi​

Which model is better based on predictive performance? We can of course find the estimators for b0,b1b_0, b_1b0​,b1​ for each respective model using the ordinary least squares method.

In the end, we get two predictions:

y^∗0(x∗)=yˉ\hat{y}_*^0(x_*) = \bar{y} y^​∗0​(x∗​)=yˉ​

y^∗1(x∗)=b0+b1x∗\hat{y}_*^1(x_*) = b_0 + b_1x_* y^​∗1​(x∗​)=b0​+b1​x∗​

Now to compare predictive performance, we consider the expected value of the squared errors:

E[(y∗−y^∗0(x∗))2]=E((y∗−yˉ)2)\begin{align*} E[(y_* - \hat{y}_*^0(x_*))^2] = E((y_* - \bar{y})^2) \end{align*} E[(y∗​−y^​∗0​(x∗​))2]=E((y∗​−yˉ​)2)​

and

E[(y∗−y^∗1(x∗))2]=E((y∗−b0−b1x∗)2)E[(y_* - \hat{y}_*^1(x_*))^2] = E((y_* - b_0 - b_1x_*)^2) E[(y∗​−y^​∗1​(x∗​))2]=E((y∗​−b0​−b1​x∗​)2)

Expanding the first identity:

E[(y∗−y^∗0(x∗))2]=Var(y∗−y^0(x∗))+E(y∗−y^0(x∗))2=Var(y∗)+Var(y^0(x∗))+E(y∗−y^0(x∗))2=σ2+Var(y^0(x∗))+E(y∗−y^0(x∗))2=σ2+Var(y^0(x∗))+Bias(y^0(x∗))2\begin{align*} E[(y_* - \hat{y}_*^0(x_*))^2] &= \text{Var}(y_* - \hat{y}^0(x_*)) + E(y_* - \hat{y}^0(x_*))^2 \\ &= \text{Var}(y_*) + \text{Var}(\hat{y}^0(x_*)) + E(y_* - \hat{y}^0(x_*))^2 \\ &= \sigma^2 + \text{Var}(\hat{y}^0(x_*)) + E(y_* - \hat{y}^0(x_*))^2 \\ &= \sigma^2 + \text{Var}(\hat{y}^0(x_*))+ \text{Bias}(\hat{y}^0(x_*))^2 \end{align*} E[(y∗​−y^​∗0​(x∗​))2]​=Var(y∗​−y^​0(x∗​))+E(y∗​−y^​0(x∗​))2=Var(y∗​)+Var(y^​0(x∗​))+E(y∗​−y^​0(x∗​))2=σ2+Var(y^​0(x∗​))+E(y∗​−y^​0(x∗​))2=σ2+Var(y^​0(x∗​))+Bias(y^​0(x∗​))2​

And by a similar reasoning:

E[(y∗−y^1(x∗))2]=σ2+Var(y^1(x∗))+[E(y∗−y^1(x∗))]2\begin{align*} E[(y_* - \hat{y}^1(x_*))^2] = \sigma^2 + \text{Var}(\hat{y}^1(x_*)) + [E(y_* - \hat{y}^1(x_*))]^2 \end{align*} E[(y∗​−y^​1(x∗​))2]=σ2+Var(y^​1(x∗​))+[E(y∗​−y^​1(x∗​))]2​

The components of model selection

Thereby, as long as we are trying to minimise the squared errors, we can decompose models into three parts:

  • Error variance
  • Variance of prediction
  • Squared bias

Thus we must try to minimise all three of these values.

Continuing further:

Var(y^0(x∗))=σ2n\text{Var}(\hat{y}^0(x_*)) = \frac{\sigma^2}{n} Var(y^​0(x∗​))=nσ2​

Var(y^1(x∗))=σ2(1n+(x∗−xˉ)2Sxx)\text{Var}(\hat{y}^1(x_*)) = \sigma^2\left(\frac{1}{n} + \frac{(x_* - \bar{x})^2}{S_{xx}}\right) Var(y^​1(x∗​))=σ2(n1​+Sxx​(x∗​−xˉ)2​)

thereby, prediction variance becomes larger for the more complex model. Consider bias:

  • If M1M_1M1​ is the correct model then E(y∗−y^1(x∗))=0E(y_* - \hat{y}^1(x_*)) = 0E(y∗​−y^​1(x∗​))=0. If we fit the model M0M_0M0​ when model M1M_1M1​ holds with a nonzero β1\beta_1β1​, then the bias term may be non-zero.
  • If M0M_0M0​ holds, then the bias term will be zero for both models.

So the bias term is always smaller (or equal) for the more complex model (as if M0M_0M0​ holds, then M1M_1M1​ must always hold).

The key idea: to make it worthwhile to add a predictor, the additional increase in prediction variance must be outweighed by a reduction in bias.

Leverage and the hat matrix

First define the hat matrix HHH, where:

H=X(XTX)−1XTH = X(X^TX)^{-1}X^T H=X(XTX)−1XT

Leverages are the diagonal elements of the hat matrix HHH.

The hat matrix (also called the projection matrix), if multiplied by a response given by the model, gives the values of the predictors that formed the response.

To interpret the hat matrix, we just observe that the vector of fitted values is:

y^=Xb=X(XTX)−1XTy=Hy\hat{y} = Xb = X(X^TX)^{-1}X^Ty = Hy y^​=Xb=X(XTX)−1XTy=Hy

It follows that the i-th fitted value y^i\hat{y}_iy^​i​ can be written as:

y^i=hiiyi+∑j≠ihijyj\hat{y}_i = h_{ii}y_i + \sum_{j\ne i}h_{ij}y_j y^​i​=hii​yi​+j=i∑​hij​yj​

The leverage is some measure of the influence of yiy_iyi​ on the fit at the iii-th set of predictor values.

Consider the following properties:

  • The matrix HHH is a real, symmetric and idempotent n×nn \times nn×n matrix
  • HX=XHX = XHX=X
  • (I−H)X=0(I - H)X = 0(I−H)X=0 and H(I−H)=0H(I - H) = 0H(I−H)=0
  • The diagonal entries of HHH always lie between zero and one.

We can also write the leverage as:

hii=xiT(XTX)−1xih_{ii} = x_i^T(X^TX)^{-1}x_i hii​=xiT​(XTX)−1xi​

and it is derivable, through the above identity that:

Var(y^(xi))=σ2hii\text{Var}(\hat{y}(x_i)) = \sigma^2h_{ii} Var(y^​(xi​))=σ2hii​

PRESS residuals/statistic

It is unwise to fit a model and then test it's goodness of fit using it's residuals on the same sample.

A better approach is to fit a model to all the data except the iii-th observation and then calculate a new kind of residual, so called the iii-th PRESS residual, given by:

ei,−i=yi−y^i,−ie_{i, -i} = y_i - \hat{y}_{i, -i} ei,−i​=yi​−y^​i,−i​

where y^i,−i\hat{y}_{i, -i}y^​i,−i​ is the prediction of the iii-th observation obtained by fitting a model to the data using all observations except the iii-th.

A global measure of goodness of fit based on the PRESS residuals is the PRESS statistic (predicted residual error sum of squares) which is the sum of the squared PRESS residuals:

PRESS=∑i=1nei,−i2\text{PRESS} = \sum_{i=1}^n e_{i, -i}^2 PRESS=i=1∑n​ei,−i2​

R code

i <- 3

# Model without the i-th point only.
hospital_mod_mi <- lm(y~x1+x2+x3+x4+x%, data=hospital[-i,])

# Model with just the i-th point.
nd <- hospital[i,]

# Find the single PRESS residual
e_mi <- hospital$y[i] - predict(hospital_mod_mi, newdata=nd)
e_mi

Leverage computation

If eie_iei​ is the ordinary residual for the iii-th observation, hiih_{ii}hii​ is the iii-th leverage value, and if ei,−ie_{i, -i}ei,−i​ is the iii-th PRESS residual, then it can be shown that:

ei,−i=ei1−hiie_{i, -i} = \frac{e_i}{1 - h_{ii}} ei,−i​=1−hii​ei​​

Interpretation of the PRESS statistic

  1. Gather all your models, and fit them
  2. For each model, calculate the PRESS statistic
  3. Choose the model with the smallest PRESS statistic - which indicates that the model has the smallest out of sample prediction error.

Cross validation

Cross validation is related to the PRESS statistic. Model selection via the PRESS statistic is sometimes called leave one out cross validation (LOOCV).

Validation set

Instead of leaving out one sample, we divide the sample into two samples, a training sample and a validation sample. Selection of a model is based on the prediction of the validation sample.

  1. Divide the data set into two parts randomly. We do this by dividing the index set I:=i=1,…NI :=i=1, \dots NI:=i=1,…N into two disjoint sets ItrI_{tr}Itr​ and ItestI_{test}Itest​.
  2. Fit each candidate model we want to select from to the training data only, i.e to all (xi,yi)(x_i, y_i)(xi​,yi​) such that i∈Itri \in I_{tr}i∈Itr​, to obtain btrb^{tr}btr.
  3. Predict to the test data only, i.e for i∈Itesti \in I_{test}i∈Itest​ calculate:

y^i=b0tr+b1trxi\hat{y}_i = b_0^{tr} + b_1^{tr}x_i y^​i​=b0tr​+b1tr​xi​

ei=yi−y^ie_i = y_i - \hat{y}_i ei​=yi​−y^​i​

VC=∑i∈Itestei2VC = \sum_{i\in I_{test}}e_{i}^2 VC=i∈Itest​∑​ei2​

  1. Take the model with the lowest validation criteria (VCVCVC) value.

There are some difficulties with the validation set approach - name:

  • How do we split the data?
  • Do we have enough data points to split the data?

K-fold cross validation

The term cross validation technically refers to randomly splitting the data into KKK (often 5 to 10) subsets of approximately equal size. Then each of the subsets are considered as testing data once, while fitting the data to the remaining K−1K-1K−1 subsets.

This process results in KKK estimates of the mean squared error, MSE1,...,MSEKMSE_1, ..., MSE_KMSE1​,...,MSEK​.

The KKK-fold CV estimate for the test MSE is computed by averaging these KKK estimates:

CV(K)=1K∑i=1KMSEiCV_{(K)} = \frac{1}{K}\sum_{i=1}^K \text{MSE}_i CV(K)​=K1​i=1∑K​MSEi​

The conceptual predictive criterion (Mallow's criterion)

We can instead create some arbitrary criterion, and then for each model we have, compute the criterion.

Importantly, this criterion/testing framework can only be useful to compare sub-models in a larger full model.

  • For a current model with ppp parameters, derive and minimise an estimate of the theoretical quantity

∑i=1nMSE(y^(xi))σ2\sum_{i=1}^n \frac{\text{MSE}(\hat{y}(x_i))}{\sigma^2} i=1∑n​σ2MSE(y^​(xi​))​

  • Now using the formula E(Z2)=Var(Z)+E(Z)2E(Z^2) = \text{Var}(Z) + E(Z)^2E(Z2)=Var(Z)+E(Z)2:

MSE(y^(xi))=Var(y^(xi))+Bias(y^(xi))2\text{MSE}(\hat{y}(x_i)) = \text{Var}(\hat{y}(x_i)) + \text{Bias}(\hat{y}(x_i))^2 MSE(y^​(xi​))=Var(y^​(xi​))+Bias(y^​(xi​))2

  • Hence the criterion becomes:

1σ2(∑i=1nVar(y^(xi))+Bias(y^(xi))2)\frac{1}{\sigma^2}\left( \sum_{i=1}^n \text{Var}(\hat{y}(x_i)) + \text{Bias}(\hat{y}(x_i))^2\right) σ21​(i=1∑n​Var(y^​(xi​))+Bias(y^​(xi​))2)

  • It can be shown that:

1σ2∑i=1nVar(y^(xi))=p\frac{1}{\sigma^2}\sum_{i=1}^n\text{Var}(\hat{y}(x_i)) = p σ21​i=1∑n​Var(y^​(xi​))=p

  • And also that (n−p)(σ^p−σ2)(n-p)(\hat{\sigma}_p - \sigma^2)(n−p)(σ^p​−σ2) is an unbiased estimator of the RHS, thereby, we finally get:

Cp=p+(σ^p2−σ^F2)(n−p)σF2C_p = p + \frac{(\hat{\sigma}_p^2 - \hat{\sigma}_F^2)(n-p)}{\sigma_F^2} Cp​=p+σF2​(σ^p2​−σ^F2​)(n−p)​

We can use a library called leaps to calculate the Mallow's criterion.

library(leaps)
cp = leaps(x=X columns, y=Y column,names=names of the X columns, method=['Cp', 'r2', 'adjr2'])

Akaike information criterion (AIC)

The Akaike information criterion (AIC) is the most commonly used criteria for model selection for applied statistician, and is defined as:

AIC=−2log⁡L^+2KAIC = -2 \log \hat{L} + 2K AIC=−2logL^+2K

where K=p+1K = p + 1K=p+1 is the number of estimated parameters in the model (ppp β\betaβ's, plus σ\sigmaσ estimated), and L^=L(β^0,β^1,...,β^k,σ^2)\hat{L} = L(\hat{\beta}_0, \hat{\beta}_1, ..., \hat{\beta}_k, \hat{\sigma}^2)L^=L(β^​0​,β^​1​,...,β^​k​,σ^2).

For all Gaussian models, we know that the log-likelihood is given by:

log⁡L=−n2log⁡(2π)−n2log⁡(σ2)−12σ2S(β)\log L = -\frac{n}{2}\log(2\pi) - \frac{n}{2}\log(\sigma^2) - \frac{1}{2\sigma^2}S(\beta) logL=−2n​log(2π)−2n​log(σ2)−2σ21​S(β)

Substituting (y−Xb)T(y−Xb)=SSres(y-Xb)^T(y-Xb) = SS_{res}(y−Xb)T(y−Xb)=SSres​ and σ2=SSres/n\sigma^2 = SS_{res}/nσ2=SSres​/n, we can derive:

AIC=nlog⁡(SSresn)+2pAIC = n\log\left( \frac{SS_{res}}{n}\right) + 2p AIC=nlog(nSSres​​)+2p

R's extractAIC uses the above expression to find the AIC value, whereas AIC uses the full expression.

model <- lm(...)
AIC(model)

Sequential variable selection procedures

  • The approaches we have seen so far compute some criterion for a possible subset of models and then choose the model with the minimum criterion
  • If the number of criterion is even moderately large (say ~100), the number of possibly models is enormous.
  • So how can we solve this issue?

Forward selection

Start with the simplest model, just the intercept model (β0\beta_0β0​).

  1. We calculate a model criterion for the current model
  2. We then try every model that has one more predictor than the current model, and calculate a model selection criteria for each of these.
  3. If any of these have a better criterion value, this becomes our new current model, and we go back to step 1.
# We can use the MASS library to do stepwise selection easily.
library(MASS)
step <- stepAIC(cheese_mod_0, scope=~Acetic+H2S+Lactic, direction="forward")
step$coefficients

Backward selection

Start with the fullest model, which uses every predictor

  1. We calculate a model criterion for the current model
  2. We then try every model that has one less predictor than the current model, and calculate the selection criteria for each of these
  3. If any of these have a better criterion value, this becomes our new current model, and we go back to step 1.
# We can use the MASS library to do stepwise selection easily.
library(MASS)
step <- stepAIC(cheese_mod_0, scope=~Acetic+H2S+Lactic, direction="backward")
step$coefficients

Least absolute shrinkage and selection operator (LASSO)

LASSO is a method that effectively performs model selection AND regression coefficient estimation simultaneously, is the recent development in model selection. In the general linear model, we minimise the least squares criterion:

S(β)=∑i=1n(yi−β0−∑j=1kxijβj)2S(\beta) = \sum_{i=1}^n\left(y_i - \beta_0 - \sum_{j=1}^kx_{ij}\beta{j}\right)^2 S(β)=i=1∑n​(yi​−β0​−j=1∑k​xij​βj)2

to estimate β\betaβ. The LASSO estimator of a linear model minimises the same sum of squares S(β)S(\beta)S(β), but subject to a constraint:

∑j=1k∣βj∣≤t\sum_{j=1}^k |\beta_j| \le t j=1∑k​∣βj​∣≤t

for some t. Thereby LASSO actually estimates for:

S(β)+λ∑i=1k∣βj∣S(\beta) + \lambda\sum_{i=1}^k |\beta_j| S(β)+λi=1∑k​∣βj​∣

This bounds our optimisations to one of the vertices of our simplex (or square). The penalty term pushes insignificant betas to 0 by our choice of λ\lambdaλ.

λ\lambdaλ is referred to as the tuning parameter.

library(glmnet)
cheese <- read.table("cheese.txt", header=T)
x <- as.matrix(cheese[,-1])
y <- cheese$taste

# cross validation path
path_cv <- cv.glmnet(x, y)
cheese_mod=glmnet(x, y,lambda=path_cv$lambda.min)
coef(cheese_mod)

Residuals and Diagnostics

Previously in model selection, we talked about critcism of models based on the estimation of parameters and how well they are "fit" based on some criterion.

In this chapter, we talk about another way of model criticism - through the analysis of residuals.

Residual plots

Residual plots can be used to visually see if residuals follow:

  1. The assumption of constantcy
  2. The assumption of normalcy

Assumptions

In the general linear model:

y=XB+ϵy = XB + \epsilon y=XB+ϵ

we assume:

  1. The errors ϵi\epsilon_iϵi​ and hence the responses yiy_iyi​ are uncorrelated, i=1,…,ni=1, \dots, ni=1,…,n.
  2. The mean of the response yiy_iyi​ is a linear combination of predictors
  3. The variance of the errors and hence the variance of yiy_iyi​ is constant
  4. (For fitting) the errors and hence yiy_iyi​ is normally distributed.

ϵi\epsilon_iϵi​ is a theoretical value. In practice, we use the residuals ei=yi−y^ie_i = y_i - \hat{y}_iei​=yi​−y^​i​ to estimate our errors.

  • In MATH2831, we do not study ways of checking assumption 1.
  • Assumption 2 can be checked by using the residuals v.s fitted values plot - which will have some shape.
  • Assumption 3 can be checked by looking for a fan shape (or more complex shape) in the spread of the residuals
  • Assumption 4 can be checked by looking for deviations from a straight line in the Q-Q plot.

Properties of residuals

Consider the general linear model with bbb as the least squares estimator. The fitted values are:

y^=Xb=X(XTX)−1XTy=Hy\begin{align*} \hat{y} &= Xb \\ &= X(X^TX)^{-1}X^Ty \\ &= Hy \end{align*} y^​​=Xb=X(XTX)−1XTy=Hy​

The vector of residuals is given by:

e=y−y^=y−Hy=(I−H)y\begin{align*} e &= y - \hat{y} \\ &= y - Hy \\ &= (I - H)y \end{align*} e​=y−y^​=y−Hy=(I−H)y​

Then, the following must be true:

E(e)=(I−H)Xβ=0E(e) = (I - H)X\beta = 0 E(e)=(I−H)Xβ=0

Var(e)=σ2(I−H)\text{Var}(e) = \sigma^2(I-H) Var(e)=σ2(I−H)

While we assumed that ϵ\epsilonϵ had constant variance, it is clear from above that eee's variance is not constant. Recall that the leverages hiih_{ii}hii​ are positive such that 0≤hii≤10 \le h_{ii} \le 10≤hii​≤1, so that the variances:

Var(ei)=σ2(1−hii)\text{Var}(e_i) = \sigma^2(1 - h_{ii}) Var(ei​)=σ2(1−hii​)

are smaller than Var(ϵi)=σ2\text{Var}(\epsilon_i) = \sigma^2Var(ϵi​)=σ2.

In general, the values of hiih_{ii}hii​ tend to zero as the value of nnn (the number of observations) grow; and thus the more samples we have, the strong our assumption of constancy is.

We can also write eee as:

e=(I−H)ϵe = (I - H)\epsilon e=(I−H)ϵ

ei=ϵI−∑j=1nhijϵje_i = \epsilon_I - \sum_{j=1}^nh_{ij}\epsilon_j ei​=ϵI​−j=1∑n​hij​ϵj​

Therefore, if ϵi\epsilon_iϵi​ is normally distributed, eee is also normally distributed by:

ei∼N(0,σ2(1−hii))e_i \sim N(0, \sigma^2(1 - h_{ii})) ei​∼N(0,σ2(1−hii​))

Cov(ei,ej)=−σ2hij,i≠j\text{Cov}(e_i, e_j) = -\sigma^2h_{ij}, i \ne j Cov(ei​,ej​)=−σ2hij​,i=j

NOTE: We cannot actually say that the vector of eee has a joint normal distribution as (I−H)(I - H)(I−H) is not invertible.

We still have the problem that eie_iei​ does not have constant variance; we can instead standardise the residual to hold this assumptio. The iii-th standardised residual can be represented as:

eiσ1−hii∼N(0,1)\frac{e_i}{\sigma\sqrt{1 - h_{ii}}} \sim N(0, 1) σ1−hii​​ei​​∼N(0,1)

But since we must estimated the actual error variance:

eiσ^1−hii\frac{e_i}{\hat{\sigma}\sqrt{1- h_{ii}}} σ^1−hii​​ei​​

Residuals and detecting outlying points

We call outlying points the single points which do not fit the overall pattern of the data, such as outliers and/or high leverage observations.

  • Raw residuals are not necessarily the most useful quantities for detecting outlying points
  • One problem is that variance of the raw residuals is not constant, even if the errors do.
  • The variance at eie_iei​ can be much less that at ϵi\epsilon_iϵi​.

Standardised PRESS residuals

What about PRESS residuals? We could use PRESS residuals as a diagnostic tool too.

Remember that:

ei,−i=ei1−hiie_{i, -i} = \frac{e_i}{1 - h_{ii}} ei,−i​=1−hii​ei​​

The raw residuals are normally distributed by

ei∼N(0,σ2(1−hii))e_i \sim N(0, \sigma^2(1-h_{ii})) ei​∼N(0,σ2(1−hii​))

and therefore PRESS residuals are too normally distributed.

Var(ei,−i)=σ21−hii\text{Var}(e_{i, -i}) = \frac{\sigma^2}{1 - h_{ii}} Var(ei,−i​)=1−hii​σ2​

Thereby, standardising for the variance, we get:

eiσ1−hii\frac{e_i}{\sigma \sqrt{1 - h_{ii}}} σ1−hii​​ei​​

So our standardised PRESS residuals and raw residuals are the same! This should be motivation for why residuals are a good diagnostic in the first place.

Externally studentized residuals

The $i$th externally studentized residual is given by:

ti=eiσ^−i1−hiit_i = \frac{e_i}{\hat{\sigma}_{-i}\sqrt{1-h_{ii}}} ti​=σ^−i​1−hii​​ei​​

where σ^−i\hat{\sigma}_{-i}σ^−i​ is the estimated error variance in the model without the iii-th observation. This is distributed by tn−p−1t_{n-p-1}tn−p−1​, as the χ2\chi^2χ2 is given by all the residuals besides one point.

The internally stuentized residual is given by:

eiσ^1−hii\frac{e_i}{\hat{\sigma}\sqrt{1-h_{ii}}} σ^1−hii​​ei​​

However since σ^\hat{\sigma}σ^ uses eie_iei​ in it's calculation, we have that they are dependent. This makes it very difficult to do robust analysis; which is why we remove the iii-th point for the sigma caclulation.

Now we begin to consider the notion of detecting outliers using tit_iti​; if the iii-th observation is an outlier, then there is the danger that σ^2\hat{\sigma}^2σ^2 is over estimated.

σ^−i=(n−p)σ^2−ei1−hiin−p−1\hat{\sigma}_{-i} = \sqrt{\frac{(n-p)\hat{\sigma}^2 - \frac{e_i}{1-h_{ii}}}{n-p-1}} σ^−i​=n−p−1(n−p)σ^2−1−hii​ei​​​​

Remember that we assume that ϵ\epsilonϵ has zero mean and constant variance. We can use the iii-th externally studentized residual to detect these problems.

Hypothesis testing using externally studentized residuals

Note for below that we define:

  1. E(ϵi)=Δi≠0E(\epsilon_i) = \Delta_i \ne 0E(ϵi​)=Δi​=0
  2. Var(ϵi)=σ2+σi2\text{Var}(\epsilon_i) = \sigma^2 + \sigma_i^2Var(ϵi​)=σ2+σi2​

Remembering that:

ti=eiσ^−i1−hii∼tn−p−1t_i = \frac{e_i}{\hat{\sigma}_{-i}\sqrt{1-h_{ii}}} \sim t_{n-p-1} ti​=σ^−i​1−hii​​ei​​∼tn−p−1​

The mean shift model is:

H0:Δi=0 v.s H1:Δi≠0H_0: \Delta_i = 0 \text{ v.s } H_1:\Delta_i \ne 0 H0​:Δi​=0 v.s H1​:Δi​=0

where E(ϵi)=ΔiE(\epsilon_i) = \Delta_iE(ϵi​)=Δi​.

The variance departure model is:

H0:σi2=0 v.s H1:σi2≠0H_0 : \sigma_i^2 = 0 \text{ v.s } H_1: \sigma_i^2 \ne 0 H0​:σi2​=0 v.s H1​:σi2​=0

To test both of these models, we can test:

p=P(∣T∣≥∣ti∣)p = P(|T| \ge |t_i|) p=P(∣T∣≥∣ti​∣)

where T tn−p−1T ~ t_{n-p-1}T tn−p−1​. If ppp-value is less than α\alphaα then a need for futher investigation of the iii-th investigation is indicated.

Importantly, we should choose the most prominent datapoint (the largest outlier) in the studentised residuals, to test whether the mean shift model and variance departure model hold.

On R, we can use rstudent(model) to do this.

Measures of influence

  • A particular observation is said to be influential, if it's inclusion/exclusion has a large impact on the inferences of interest in a study.
  • Externally studentiszed residuals and leverages can help to identify influential observations.
  • In the figure above we see the removal of two points and the influence it has on the regression (red line).
  • While visually it seems both would have a similar amount of influence when removed, it is clear that the first point removed has much more influence.
  • This illustrates that both high leverage and residuals are required to be influential.

A demonstrative example

Consider a study where we want to investigate the amount of a drug that is present in the liver of a rat. The rats were given a dose relative to their body weight.

It we hypothesised that there is no relationship between the dose in the liver (yyy) and the body weight (x1x_1x1​), liver weight (x2x_2x2​) and relative dose (x3x_3x3​).

When we ran lm on the dataset, we get a p-value of 0.072 on the F-test, which means that there is no significant relationship. But how can we explain this?

First we check hatvalues() using dotchart(hatvalues(model)) which yields:

There is clearly a lot of influence on the 3rd leverage. Also considering the externally studentized residuals using dotchart(rstudent(model)):

Nothing stands out in the residuals plot. To test whether these values are unusually large, there are various approaches:

  • For leverages, we could say anything larger than 2pn\frac{2p}{n}n2p​ is large; as pn\frac{p}{n}np​ is the average residual value.
  • For standardised residuals, we can check for observations greater than 2 in absolute value
  • For externally studentised residuals, we can compare with the ttt distribution.

Removing the 3rd point, we see the F-test p-value become 0.958 (!!!). The single point had an immense amount of influence which lead the model to seem more accurate than it should have.

A more automated way to find high influence observations is influence.measure(model).

Metrics for influence

Cook's distance

The motivation for Cook's distance comes from an attempt to measure the change in the estimated parameters when an observation is deleted.

  • b−ib_{-i}b−i​ is the fit parameters without the iii-th observation
  • bbb is the usual fit parameters for all observations.
  • σ^2\hat{\sigma}^2σ^2 is the unbiased estimator of σ2\sigma^2σ2
  • then, Cook's distance is given by:

Di=(b−b−i)TXTX(b−bi)pσ^2D_i = \frac{(b - b_{-i})^TX^TX(b - b_i)}{p\hat{\sigma}^2} Di​=pσ^2(b−b−i​)TXTX(b−bi​)​

or a more computationally easy calculation is:

Di=ri2p×hii1−hiiD_i = \frac{r_i^2}{p} \times \frac{h_{ii}}{1-h_{ii}} Di​=pri2​​×1−hii​hii​​

Remember the confidence ellipsoid defined by:

(b−β)TXX(b−β)pσ^2∼Fp,n−p\frac{(b-\beta)^TX^X(b-\beta)}{p\hat{\sigma}^2} \sim F_{p, n-p} pσ^2(b−β)TXX(b−β)​∼Fp,n−p​

Given this, if we compare Cook's distance to the 50 percentage point of the F-distribution, we are saying that the deletion of the iii-th case moves the estimate of the parameters outside a 50 percent confidence interval for β\betaβ based on how we fit the data.

Any observation with a Cook distance > 1 is an influential point, and anything above > 0.5 may want to be looked at.

DFFITS

DFFITS looks at the change in the fitted value at the i-th point upon deletion of the i-th case. DFFITS is defined to be:

DFFITSi=y^i−y^i,−iσ^−ihii\text{DFFITS}_i = \frac{\hat{y}_i - \hat{y}_{i, -i}}{\hat{\sigma}_{-i}\sqrt{h_{ii}}} DFFITSi​=σ^−i​hii​​y^​i​−y^​i,−i​​

DFFITS is estimating the number of standard errors the prediction moves at the deletion of the iii-th observation. DFFITS can also be computed without refitting the model, by:

DFFITSi=tihii1−hii\text{DFFITS}_i = t_i \sqrt{\frac{h_{ii}}{1 - h_{ii}}} DFFITSi​=ti​1−hii​hii​​​

where tit_iti​ is the externally studentized residual for the iii-th point.

DFBETAS

DFBETAS instead considers how much the jjj-th coefficient estimate changes at the deletion of the iii-th observation. This is defined by:

DFBETASj,i=bj−bj,−iσ^−icjj\text{DFBETAS}_{j, i} = \frac{b_j - b_{j, -i}}{\hat{\sigma}_{-i}\sqrt{c_{jj}}} DFBETASj,i​=σ^−i​cjj​​bj​−bj,−i​​

where bjb_jbj​ is the jjj-th element of bbb, and bj,−i,σ−ib_{j, -i}, \sigma_{-i}bj,−i​,σ−i​ is the fitted values of b and estimated σ\sigmaσ without the iii-th observation.

COVRATIO

COVRATIO measures the effect of deletion of observations on the estimated standard errors of the coefficients β\betaβ.

The COVRATIO for the iii-th observation is given by:

COVRATIOi=∣σ^−i2(X−iTX−i)−1∣∣σ^2(XTX)−1∣=Det(σ^−i2(X−iTX−i))Det(σ^2(XTX)−1)\text{COVRATIO}_i = \frac{|\hat{\sigma}_{-i}^2(X_{-i}^TX_{-i})^{-1}|}{|\hat{\sigma}^2(X^TX)^{-1}|} = \frac{\text{Det}(\hat{\sigma}_{-i}^2(X_{-i}^TX_{-i}))}{\text{Det}(\hat{\sigma}^2(X^TX)^{-1})} COVRATIOi​=∣σ^2(XTX)−1∣∣σ^−i2​(X−iT​X−i​)−1∣​=Det(σ^2(XTX)−1)Det(σ^−i2​(X−iT​X−i​))​

COVRATIO can also be defined by:

COVRATIOi=σ^−i2pσ^2p11−hii\text{COVRATIO}_i = \frac{\hat{\sigma}^{2p}_{-i}}{\hat{\sigma}^{2p}}\frac{1}{1-h_{ii}} COVRATIOi​=σ^2pσ^−i2p​​1−hii​1​

Computation in R

All of these influence metrics can be found in one command using

infl <- influence.measures(model)$infmat

# if you just do influence.measures(model), you will get a 
# matrix of all the values for each i-th observation

To chart them, consider the following example:

dotchart(infl[,"dfb.Livr"],xlab="dfb.Livr",ylab="observation")

Dealing with violations of assumptions

When we detect violations in assumptions we can fix them in two main ways:

  1. Transformation
  2. Modelling solution

Variance stabilising transformations of the response

We first consider transformations available to use when the assumption of constant error variance is violated.

It is common for the variance in a linear regression to rely on the mean level.

This of course means the variance grows and shrinks with the mean level, which is particularly alarming in something like a time series.

Common transformation include:

  • square root transformation y→yy \to \sqrt{y}y→y​
  • log transform y→log⁡(y)y \to \log(y)y→log(y) or y→log⁡(1+y)y \to \log(1 + y)y→log(1+y)
  • reciprocal transform to y→1yy \to \frac{1}{y}y→y1​ or y→11+yy \to \frac{1}{1 + y}y→1+y1​
  • Logit transform y→log⁡(y1−y)y \to \log\left(\frac{y}{1-y}\right)y→log(1−yy​) when y∈(0,1)y \in (0, 1)y∈(0,1)

In general, to justify the above transformations, suppose fff is a smooth function. Then the first order Taylor series expansion of f(yi)f(y_i)f(yi​) around E(yi)E(y_i)E(yi​) is given by:

f(yi)=f(E(yi))+f′(E(yi))(yi−E(yi))f(y_i) = f(E(y_i)) + f'(E(y_i))(y_i - E(y_i)) f(yi​)=f(E(yi​))+f′(E(yi​))(yi​−E(yi​))

and the variance is then given by:

Var(f(yi))=f′(E(yi))2Var(yi)\text{Var}(f(y_i)) = f'(E(y_i))^2\text{Var}(y_i) Var(f(yi​))=f′(E(yi​))2Var(yi​)

You then sub in the appropiate values for the distribution of YYY, for example Y∼Poisson(λ)Y \sim \text{Poisson}(\lambda)Y∼Poisson(λ).

Evaluating transformations

  • If we are interested in inference, then we want to check if the transformed linear model now meets the assumptions of a linear model.
  • It is of course important to realise that the transformation moves the scale, and that R2R^2R2 values and error standard deviation's definitions change under transformation.
  • If we are interested in prediction, we might want to check the PRESS statistics for the transformed and untransformed models. However since the data is on different scales:
    • We apply the variance stabilising transformation z=f(y)z=f(y)z=f(y) and fit a linear regression to zzz
    • Write z^i,−i\hat{z}_{i, -i}z^i,−i​ for zi−z^i,−iz_i - \hat{z}_{i, -i}zi​−z^i,−i​ for the PRESS residual on the new zzz scale.
    • However we are interested in prediction in the original scale, so consider the PRESS residual on the original scale is: yi−f−1(z^i,−i)y_i - f^{-1}(\hat{z}_{i, -i})yi​−f−1(z^i,−i​).
    • We can calculate and compare for the original model:

    ∑i=1n(yi−f−1(z^i,−i))2\sum_{i=1}^n(y_i - f^{-1}(\hat{z}_{i, -i}))^2 i=1∑n​(yi​−f−1(z^i,−i​))2

Weighted Least Squares Regression

When constant error variance assumptions are violated, transformations are a common way of dealing with them.

However, another approach is to change the model to allow a variance which is not constant.

Suppose we know that the errors ϵ\epsilonϵ have mean 0, but have Var(ϵi)=σi2\text{Var}(\epsilon_i) = \sigma_i^2Var(ϵi​)=σi2​, or in other words, suppose Var(ϵi)=σ2wi\text{Var}(\epsilon_i) = \frac{\sigma^2}{w_i}Var(ϵi​)=wi​σ2​ where wiw_iwi​ is some weight. In this case, weighted least squares can be applied.

Write VVV for the covariance matrix of errors - V is a diagonal matrix with diagonal elements σi2\sigma_i^2σi2​ or σ2/wi\sigma^2/w_iσ2/wi​, in which case V=σ2W−1V = \sigma^2W^{-1}V=σ2W−1, where WWW is the diagonal matrix of weights.

Given a diagonal matrix WWW of positive weights, the weighted least squares problem is to minimise:

S(β,W)=(y−Xβ)TW(y−Xβ)=∑i=1nwi(yi−xiTβ)2\begin{align*} S(\beta, W) &= (y - X\beta)^TW(y-X\beta) \\ &= \sum_{i=1}^n w_i(y_i - x_i^T\beta)^2\end{align*} S(β,W)​=(y−Xβ)TW(y−Xβ)=i=1∑n​wi​(yi​−xiT​β)2​

or alternatively, with the covariance matrix VVV approach, it can be proven with likelihood functions that the maximum likelihood estimator of β\betaβ is given by:

β^=(XTV−1X)−1(XTV−1y)\hat{\beta} = (X^TV^{-1}X)^{-1}(X^TV^{-1}y) β^​=(XTV−1X)−1(XTV−1y)

and for the weighted approach:

bw=(XTWX)−1(XTWy)b^{w} = (X^TWX)^{-1}(X^TWy) bw=(XTWX)−1(XTWy)

When the weights or σi2\sigma_i^2σi2​ are known, weighted regression may be preferred over transformations. Weighted least squares is an extension of a much broader topic, generalised least squares, which takes the form:

S(β,V)=(y−Xβ)TV−1(y−Xβ)S(\beta, V) = (y-X\beta)^TV^{-1}(y-X\beta) S(β,V)=(y−Xβ)TV−1(y−Xβ)

Categorical predictors and interactions

We have investigated quantitative predictors with quantitative responses for the entire course. This module investigates how we investigate categorical predictors with quantitative responses; revising ways to analyse categorical predictors in their statistical significance and more.

Categorical predictors with two levels

To consider categorical predictors, we code them with numerical values. Consider the inflation data, where DEV is a categorical variable which considers if the country is developed or developing. We "code" the predictor as:

wi={1country i is developed0country i is developing w_i = \begin{cases} 1 & \text{country i is developed} \\ 0 & \text{country i is developing} \end{cases}wi​={10​country i is developedcountry i is developing​

We have coded (DEV) into a quantitative predictor which takes value 0 or 1. Now the model becomes:

yi=β0+β1xi+β2wi+ϵiy_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1x_i + \beta_2w_i + \epsilon_i yi​=β0​+β1​xi​+β2​wi​+ϵi​

where the β0,β1\beta_0, \beta_1β0​,β1​ and β2\beta_2β2​ are unknown parameters and ϵi∼N(0,σ2)\epsilon_i \sim N(0, \sigma^2)ϵi​∼N(0,σ2).

The expectation becomes:

E(yi)={β0+β2+β1xicountry i is developedβ0+β1xicountry i is developing E(y_i) = \begin{cases} \beta_0 + \beta_2 + \beta_1x_i & \text{country i is developed} \\ \beta_0 + \beta_1x_i & \text{country i is developing} \end{cases}E(yi​)={β0​+β2​+β1​xi​β0​+β1​xi​​country i is developedcountry i is developing​

So β2\beta_2β2​ is the expected change in the response between the two groups. Now that we have codified our predictor, we can do hypothesis testing on β2\beta_2β2​ as with any other predictor using summary(model). R is also able to codify our categorical predictors for us.

A two-level categorical predictor essentially creates two parallel lines for the model. One where the predictor holds one value and one where the predictor holds the other. It should be a linear transformation of the β\betaβ to the predictor.

Interactions

Interactions, however, allows us to have non-parallel lines for different categorical variables. It essentially considers the interaction between a categorical predictor and another predictor - does one influence the other?

The previous model with interaction now looks like:

yi=β0+β1xi+β2wi+β3wixi+ϵiy_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1x_i + \beta_2w_i + \beta_3w_ix_i + \epsilon_i yi​=β0​+β1​xi​+β2​wi​+β3​wi​xi​+ϵi​

where β3wixi\beta_3w_ix_iβ3​wi​xi​ is the interaction term.

The expectation is given by:

E(yi)={β0+β2+(β1+β3)xicountry i is developedβ0+β1xicountry i is developing E(y_i) = \begin{cases} \beta_0 + \beta_2 + (\beta_1 + \beta_3)x_i &\text{country i is developed} \\ \beta_0 + \beta_1x_i &\text{country i is developing} \end{cases}E(yi​)={β0​+β2​+(β1​+β3​)xi​β0​+β1​xi​​country i is developedcountry i is developing​

β2\beta_2β2​ is the change in y-intercept between the groups where β3\beta_3β3​ is the change in slope between in the groups.

We can test the two using hypothesis testing:

  • If β3≠0\beta_3 \ne 0β3​=0 then there is an interaction between the two groups
  • If β2≠β3≠0\beta_2 \ne \beta_3 \ne 0β2​=β3​=0, then there is a difference between the groups

In R, we write interacting variables as Predictor1:Predictor2.

Categorical predictors with three or more levels

For r categories, we require r-1 dummy variables. We define it the same as the 2 level categorical predictor, where 1 is some category and 0 is without category. For example, for a categorical predictor with values electricity, heating oil or natural gas, we have:

w1={1if z is "electricity"0otherwise w_1 = \begin{cases} 1 & \text{if z is "electricity"} \\ 0 & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}w1​={10​if z is "electricity"otherwise​

w2={1if z is "heating oil"0otherwise w_2 = \begin{cases} 1 & \text{if z is "heating oil"} \\ 0 & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}w2​={10​if z is "heating oil"otherwise​

If zzz is gas, then both would be 0. If zzz is electricity, then only w1w_1w1​ would be 1, etc.

Example

Call:
lm(formula = Price ~ Size + Heating, data = real)

Residuals:
     Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
 -8.7490  -4.2030  -1.4700   3.6880  15.6530 

Coefficients:
                   Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)
